{"uri": "8150162165", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:12:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:12:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:11:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.adn.com/nation-world/2024/05/28/key-prosecution-witness-lied-in-hush-money-trial-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments/", "title": "Key prosecution witness lied in hush money trial, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundational premises of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential election to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nBlanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he was signing and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "adn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anchorage Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-05-371108527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:25:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:25:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:45:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money/article_67bad8e9-4ccc-50cf-9177-902df352a12d.html", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundational premises of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential election to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nBlanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he was signing and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.\n\nMore from this section\n\nClosing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms in Trump hush money trial\n\nBill Walton, Hall of Fame player who became a star broadcaster, dies of cancer at 71\n\nAt least 22 dead in Memorial Day weekend storms that devastated several US states", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@kulr8.com", "name": "Michael R. Sisak", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@kulr8.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jennifer_peltz@kulr8.com", "name": "Jennifer {"uri": "8150061345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:05:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:05:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:04:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/28/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-juror/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "Steven Hirsch / New York Post via AP\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks at Manhattan Criminal court, Monday, May 20, 2024, in New York.\n\nBy Michael R. Sisak, Jennifer Peltz, Eric Tucker and Jill Colvin, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, May 28, 2024 | 8:01 a.m.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jennifer_peltz@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Jennifer Peltz", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Michael R. "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 97}], "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/5/28/donald-trump-1-6903548-1716910086323.jpg", "originalArticle": null, {"uri": "8150068575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:09:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:09:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:08:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The debates are expected to last all day. Follow live updates. Trump faces 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nPresident Trump is innocent. He committed no crime and the prosecutor failed to meet the burden of proof, period, said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should make you leave you hungry.\n\nIn an hour-long speech to the jury, Blanche attacked the basic premise of the case, which accuses Trump of conspiring to conceal cash payments that prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the presidential election of 2016 to quell a claim by pornographic actors that she had had sex. meeting with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nBlanche countered the lawsuits' portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid close attention to the checks he signed and rejected the notion that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\nEvery campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people working together to help someone win, Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summaries represent a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks to reporters outside Manhattan Criminal Court on May 21, 2024 in New York. Santiago/Pool Photo via AP, File)\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will present their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges, while defense lawyers aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting Michael Cohen's credibility. (Elizabeth Williams via AP)\n\nTrump faces 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek prison time if convicted, or whether the judge would impose that sentence if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. . Trump denied Daniels' account, and her lawyer, during hours of questioning at the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were recorded as being for legal services, which prosecutors say were intended to conceal the true purpose of the Daniels transaction and illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers say these were legitimate payments for genuine legal services, and they say his celebrity, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen actually worked on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen described this work as very minimal, Blanche claimed the opposite.\n\nCohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you, Blanche said, her voice becoming more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from reimbursement mechanisms, saying the checks to Cohen were signed while Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to testimony from a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors he never spoke to Trump about how to characterize payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or on the phone, without knowing what they were about.\n\nAmong the nearly two dozen witnesses were Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the meeting she said she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said he used his media company to protect Trump by suppressing stories that could harm his campaign, including paying a former Playboy model $150,000 to prevent him from going public with a claim that she had a year-long affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the secret money discussions. Just pay him, the now-disbarred lawyer said, quoting Trump.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving Playboy model Karen McDougal. Trump also denied any relationship with McDougal.\n\nDefense attorneys called two witnesses, neither from Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, emphasizing his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nUnder cross-examination, for example, Cohen admitted to stealing tens of thousands of dollars from the Trump Company by demanding to be reimbursed for money he didn't spend. Cohen admitted to once telling a prosecutor that he felt Daniels and his lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to retake the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It is unclear whether any of the others will be tried before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. {"uri": "8150057968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:03:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:03:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:02:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.santacruzsentinel.com/2024/05/27/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN (Associated Press)\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "santacruzsentinel.com", {"uri": "8150261706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:26:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:26:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:24:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2953336-trumps-legal-defense-challenges-hush-money-allegations", "title": "Trump's Legal Defense Challenges Hush Money Allegations | Law-Order", "body": "Donald Trump's defense team vigorously challenged the credibility of star witness Michael Cohen in the hush money case, asserting Trump's innocence in the alleged interference in the 2016 election. The closing arguments aimed to cast doubt on charges related to falsifying business records and concealing hush money payments.\n\nDonald Trump's defence team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,'' said defence attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.'' In an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything'' approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Blanche said of Cohen. \"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\" After closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a USD 130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterised that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on October 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\" Blanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organisation controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterise the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying USD 150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-371022159", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:05:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:05:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T04:01:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.mcall.com/2024/05/28/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN (Associated Press)\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "mcall.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-371176545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:39:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:39:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T04:01:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2024/05/27/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN (Associated Press)\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's defense team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Blanche said of Cohen. \"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying $150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "eastbaytimes.com", {"uri": "8150063588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:06:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:06:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:05:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.twincities.com/2024/05/27/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By Michael R. Sisak | Associated Press, Jennifer Peltz | Associated Press, Eric Tucker | The Associated Press and Michelle Price | mprice@ap.org | Associated Press\n\nBy MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN (Associated Press)\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the testimony of a prosecution witness who told lies on the stand and cannot be trusted, a defense lawyer said Tuesday during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former American president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the election in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "twincities.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Twin Cities"}, "authors": [{"uri": "eric_tucker@twincities.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jennifer_peltz@twincities.com", "name": "Jennifer Peltz", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@twincities.com", "name": "Michael R. {"uri": "2024-05-371155864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:15:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:15:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.wsiltv.com/news/crime/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money/article_9a2a5e6a-c559-5282-9784-79f492aed4c3.html", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's defense team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Blanche said of Cohen. \"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying $150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "wsiltv.com", "dataType": "news",
