{"uri": "8150000369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:24:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:24:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:23:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/28/defense-lawyer-tells-jury-trump-is-innocent-in-closing-arguments-for-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Defense lawyer tells jury Trump is innocent in hush money trial's closing arguments", "body": "Former President Donald Trump arrives at Manhattan criminal court for closing arguments in his criminal hush money trial in New York, on Tuesday, May 28, 2024. Andrew Kelly/Pool Photo via AP\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" on the stand and cannot be trusted.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys are aiming to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan in his chambers in New York, March 14, 2024. AP Photo/Seth Wenig, File\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. {"uri": "2024-05-370969140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:17:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:17:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T09:24:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/trump-is-innocent-defense-lawyer-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Trump is 'innocent,' defense lawyer tells jury as closing arguments get underway in hush money trial", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" on the stand and cannot be trusted.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys are aiming to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "eventUri": "eng-9601578", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1686274509803921, "wgt": 218, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8150263206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:27:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:27:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:25:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money-trial-5996942.html", "title": "World News | Key Witness Lied on Stand, Trump Lawyer Tells Jurors During Closing Arguments in Hush Money Trial | LatestLY", "body": "New York, May 28 (AP) Donald Trump's defence team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\nAlso Read | Pakistan Road Accident: Eight Members of Family Killed After Jeep Falls Into Deep Ravine in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nAlso Read | Papua New Guinea Landslide: India Announces Aide of USD 1 Million for Landslide-Hit Nation.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Blanche said of Cohen. \"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a USD 130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Cohen characterised that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on October 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organisation controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterise the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer. Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying USD 150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election. "https://st1.latestly.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Latestly-World-News-784x441.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9601578", "eventUri": "eng-9601578", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-05-371018771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:02:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:02:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T04:01:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.santacruzsentinel.com/2024/05/27/trump-is-innocent-defense-lawyer-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Trump is 'innocent,' defense lawyer tells jury as closing arguments get underway in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN (Associated Press)\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" on the stand and cannot be trusted.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys are aiming to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "santacruzsentinel.com", {"uri": "8150070886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:13:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:13:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:10:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-trump-is-innocent-defence-lawyer-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-hush-money-trial-5996669.html", "title": "World News | Trump is 'innocent,' Defence Lawyer Tells Jury as Closing Arguments Get Underway in Hush Money Trial | LatestLY", "body": "New York, May 28 (AP) Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments on Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\nAlso Read | Pakistan Road Accident: Eight Members of Family Killed After Jeep Falls Into Deep Ravine in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" on the stand and cannot be trusted.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Blanche said. \"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAlso Read | Papua New Guinea Landslide: India Announces Aide of USD 1 Million for Landslide-Hit Nation.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys are aiming to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said, adding that Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion.\n\nBlanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump. "https://st1.latestly.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Latestly-World-News-784x441.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9601578", "eventUri": "eng-9601578", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-05-371250245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:12:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:12:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:15:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.wtva.com/news/national/key-witness-lied-on-stand-trump-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-in-hush-money/article_9ab913d0-0bea-5b4e-b5fe-99495a29a65b.html", "title": "Key witness lied on stand, Trump lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments in hush money trial", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JILL COLVIN - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump's defense team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nIn an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee just months before the November election. The political implications of the proceedings were unmistakable as President Joe Biden's campaign staged an event outside the courthouse with actor Robert De Niro while Blanche reminded jurors that the case was not a referendum on their views about Trump.\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nMimicking the term \"GOAT,\" used primarily in sports as an acronym for \"greatest of all time,\" Blanche labeled Cohen the \"GLOAT\" -- greatest liar of all time. The lawyer also called Cohen \"the human embodiment of reasonable doubt.\" That language was intentional because, to convict Trump, jurors must believe that prosecutors proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\n\"He lied to you repeatedly. He lied many, many times before you even met him. His financial and personal well-being depend on this case. He is biased and motivated to tell you a story that is not true,\" Blanche said.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nBefore prosecutors began closing arguments, Judge Juan M. Merchan urged jurors to disregard what he said was an \"improper\" comment by Blanche that the panel should not send Trump to prison. Merchan said that decision was his alone.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nIn his testimony, Cohen acknowledged a litany of past lies, many of which he said were intended to protect Trump. But he said he had subsequently told the truth, at great cost: \"My entire life has been turned upside-down as a direct result,\" he said.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organization controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterize the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer, and to another Trump aide who said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying $150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "wtva.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTVA 9 Tupelo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wtva.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@wtva.com", "name": "Michael R. {"uri": "8150155622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:08:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:08:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:07:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.bridportnews.co.uk/news/national/24350704.key-witness-lied-donald-trumps-lawyer-tells-jurors-closing-arguments/", "title": "Key witness lied, Donald Trump's lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "The arguments, expected to last the entire day, give lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\".\n\nIn an hours-long address to the jury, Mr Blanche attacked the foundational premises of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential election to stifle an adult film actress's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nMr Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the cheques he was signing and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Mr Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than a month of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent an adult film actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyers aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Mr Blanche said, adding that Mr Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple\".\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments on Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions - \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they will not be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence - and there were many.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan, for instance, fined Trump 10,000 dollars (\u00a37,800) for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election.\n\nBut it is unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November {"uri": "2024-05-371106776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:24:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:24:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T13:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.surreynowleader.com/world-news/closing-arguments-underway-in-trump-hush-money-trial-7365944", "title": "Closing arguments underway in Trump hush money trial", "body": "Trump faces 34 counts of falsifying business records, punishable by up to 4 years in prison\n\nDonald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nREAD ALSO: What we've learned so far in the Trump hush money trial", "source": {"uri": "surreynowleader.com", {"uri": "8150344614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:34:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:34:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2953419-trumps-defence-battles-hush-money-allegations-in-court-showdown", "title": "Trump's Defence Battles Hush Money Allegations in Court Showdown | Law-Order", "body": "Donald Trump's defence team vigorously contested the hush money case against him, labeling star witness Michael Cohen as a liar. Closing arguments aimed to discredit weeks of testimony alleging Trump interfered in the 2016 election. Jurors now face the decision of convicting the former president on felony charges.\n\nDonald Trump's defence team attacked the hush money case against him Tuesday by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of testimony that prosecutors say prove the former president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,'' said defence attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.'' In an hourslong address to the jury, Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle a porn actor's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything'' approach, Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the checks he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the porn actor, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee just months before the November election. The political implications of the proceedings were unmistakable as President Joe Biden's campaign staged an event outside the courthouse with actor Robert De Niro while Blanche reminded jurors that the case was not a referendum on their views about Trump.\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defence attorneys aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen. Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nMimicking the term \"GOAT,\" used primarily in sports as an acronym for \"greatest of all time,\" Blanche labelled Cohen the \"GLOAT'' -- greatest liar of all time. The lawyer also called Cohen \"the human embodiment of reasonable doubt.\" That language was intentional because, to convict Trump, jurors must believe that prosecutors proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\n\"He lied to you repeatedly. He lied many, many times before you even met him. His financial and personal well-being depend on this case. He is biased and motivated to tell you a story that is not true,\" Blanche said.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nBefore prosecutors began closing arguments, Judge Juan M. Merchan urged jurors to disregard what he said was an \"improper\" comment by Blanche that the panel should not send Trump to prison. Merchan said that decision was his alone.\n\nThe case centres on a USD 130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services. Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and testimony showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year. While Cohen characterised that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe attorney's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Blanche sought to unravel Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\nCohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting a hold of Trump, but Blanche asserted that at the time Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie, and he got caught red-handed.\" In his testimony, Cohen acknowledged a litany of past lies, many of which he said were intended to protect Trump. But he said he had subsequently told the truth, at great cost: \"My entire life has been turned upside-down as a direct result,\" he said.\n\nBlanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying checks to Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the testimony of a former Trump Organisation controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterise the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer, and to another Trump aide who said Trump would sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions. \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying USD 150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Biden. It's unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-370970605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:18:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:18:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T13:54:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/trump-is-innocent-defense-lawyer-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-hush-money/article_0f518a81-45c6-5df5-8481-65c33433a8ea.html", "title": "Trump is 'innocent,' defense lawyer tells jury as closing arguments get underway in hush money trial", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of former President Donald Trump at https://apnews.com/hub/donald-trump.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@register-herald.com", "name": "Michael R. {"uri": "8150105113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:33:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:33:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:33:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/world/key-witness-lied-donald-trumps-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-3SMWVFWPS5JXRKUT4VPRRPHEIE/", "title": "Key witness lied, Donald Trump's lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "The former US president denies 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nDonald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the evidence of a prosecution witness who told lies in the witness box and cannot be trusted, a defence lawyer said during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former US president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\".\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Mr Blanche said.\n\n\"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent an adult film actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyers aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Mr Blanche said, adding that Mr Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple\".\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments on Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions - \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they will not be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence - and there were many.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan, for instance, fined Trump 10,000 dollars (\u00a37,800) for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election.\n\nBut it is unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November
