{"uri": "2024-05-371121264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/defense-lawyer-closing-arguments-trump-hush-money-case-9357654/", "title": "Defense lawyer begins delivering closing arguments in Trump's hush money case", "body": "Closing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former US president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions. Trump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nAlso Read | Michael Cohen to face more grilling as Donald Trump's hush money trial enters its final stretch\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden. The other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently: --\n\nHere's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nAlso Read | Trump's defense rests case in hush money trial without calling him as witness\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election. \"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.\n\nDEFENSE BEGINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him. \"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nMERCHAN EXPLAINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROCESS\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last. Merchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday. Defense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2\u00bd hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nTHE SCENE IN THE COURTROOM\n\nDonald Trump stood and looked back for a moment after he arrived at the defense table for the start of closing arguments in his hush money trial. Sitting between two of his attorneys -- Todd Blanche and Emil Bove -- the former president appeared animated before the proceedings began, gesturing and chatting with his lawyers. Seated behind Trump are members of his family, including his sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. and his daughter Tiffany.\n\nTRUMP: IT'S 'A DARK DAY IN AMERICA'\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\" The former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\nAlso Read | Libertarians skip over Trump and RFK Jr. for Chase Oliver\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said. He was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.\n\nTRUMP ARRIVES AT COURTHOUSE\n\nA small of supporters yelled \"We love Trump\" outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning as Donald Trump's motorcade arrived. The supporters waved American flags and were wearing red \"Make America Great Again\" hats. Inside, the prosecution team made its way into the courtroom, led by Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass, who is expected to make the prosecution's closing argument. As has been his routine, Steinglass walked in carrying a file box full of papers.\n\nTRUMP FAMILY MEMBERS WILL BE IN COURT\n\nSeveral of Donald Trump's family members plan to be at court Tuesday for his hush money trial. They include his sons, Don Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, daughter-in-law Lara Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos. Other family members have not yet joined him in court, including his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and his eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump.\n\nWHAT HAPPENS DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS?\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will have their final opportunity to address the jury in closing arguments. The arguments don't count as evidence in the case charging Donald Trump with falsifying business records to cover up hush money payments during the 2016 presidential election. They'll instead function as hourslong recaps of the key points the lawyers want to leave jurors with before the panel disappears behind closed doors for deliberations. Jurors over the course of a month have heard testimony about sex and bookkeeping, tabloid journalism and presidential politics. Their task ahead will be to decide whether prosecutors who have charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business records have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\nWHAT MUST BE PROVED FOR A CONVICTION?\n\nWith closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial expected to get underway Tuesday morning, jurors have a weighty task ahead of them -- deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of some, all or none of the 34 felony counts he's charged with. To convict Trump of felony falsifying business records, prosecutors must convince jurors beyond a reasonable doubt that he not only falsified or caused business records to be entered falsely but also did so with intent to commit or conceal another crime.\n\nAlso Read | Trump's attacks on early voting muddle Republican election plans\n\nAny verdict must be unanimous. To prevent a conviction, the defense simply needs to convince at least one juror that prosecutors haven't proved Trump's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard for criminal cases.\n\nNew York also has a misdemeanor falsifying business records charge, which requires proving only that a defendant made or caused the false entries, but it is not part of Trump's case and will not be considered by jurors.\n\nA SEAT IN COURT DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROVES ALLURING FOR SOME\n\nFor many Americans, Memorial Day weekend was a moment to remember the sacrifices of U.S. military personnel and to unplug from the bustle of daily life. For others, it was a chance to snag a prime spot in line for entry into Donald Trump's hush money trial ahead of Tuesday's closing arguments.\n\nLast Friday afternoon saw several people camped out -- including professional line sitters with pup tents -- for a chance to see the tail end of the historic proceedings up close and personal. Though most of the seats inside the courtroom are reserved for lawyers, members of Trump's entourage, security personnel and journalists, a few are open to the general public.\n\nThe former president's Manhattan trial has drawn visitors from all over, including students from local schools and plenty of out-of-towners.\n\nWHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are expected to begin on Tuesday, marking the beginning of the end of the historic proceedings that kicked off in April.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will make their final pitch to jurors, hoping to sway them in one direction or another after more than four weeks of witness testimony. Following the conclusion of closing arguments, which are expected to last all day, Judge Juan M. Merchan will spend about an hour instructing the jury on the law governing the case, providing a roadmap for what it can and cannot take into account as it evaluates the Republican former president's guilt or innocence.\n\nJurors could begin deliberations as early as Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-371180410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:44:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:44:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:44:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.edp24.co.uk/news/national/24350704.key-witness-lied-donald-trumps-lawyer-tells-jurors-closing-arguments/", "title": "Key witness lied, Donald Trump's lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "Donald Trump's defence team attacked the hush money case against him by calling the star witness a liar, seeking to discredit weeks of evidence that prosecutors say prove the former US president interfered in the 2016 election through a scheme to suppress stories seen as harmful to his campaign.\n\nThe closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\".\n\nIn an hours-long address to the jury, Mr Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle an adult film actress's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Mr Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the cheques he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the adult film actress, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Mr Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyerss aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Mr Blanche said of Mr Cohen.\n\n\"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to Ms Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services.\n\nMr Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and evidence showing that Mr Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Mr Cohen characterised that work as \"very minimal\", Mr Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe lawyer's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Mr Blanche sought to unravel Mr Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on October 24 2016.\n\nMr Cohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting hold of Trump, but Mr Blanche asserted that at the time Mr Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\nMr Blanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying cheques to Mr Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the evidence of a former Trump Organisation controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterise the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer.\n\nMr Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign cheques while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions.\n\n\"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nIt is unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.", {"uri": "8150108491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:35:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:35:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:35:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/key-witness-lied-donald-trumps-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments-1631001.html", "title": "Key witness lied, Donald Trump's lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Donald Trump's landmark hush money trial turns on the evidence of a prosecution witness who told lies in the witness box and cannot be trusted, a defence lawyer said during closing arguments as he pressed jurors for an acquittal in the first criminal case against a former US president.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, give lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating Trump's fate.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\".\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Mr Blanche said.\n\n\"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than a month of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent an adult film actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyers aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Mr Blanche said, adding that Mr Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple\".\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments on Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions - \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they will not be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence - and there were many.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan, for instance, fined Trump 10,000 dollars (\u00a37,800) for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election.\n\nBut it is unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November "https://img.resized.co/breaking--witness-lied-donald-trump-s-lawyer-tells-jurors-during-closing-arguments.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9601578", "eventUri": "eng-9601578", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8150128264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:49:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:49:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:48:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/trump-defense-lawyer-former-us-president-is-innocent-in-hush-money-case/7629962.html", "title": "Trump defense lawyer: former US president is innocent in hush money case", "body": "The final scenes of Donald Trump's New York hush money criminal trial started to unfold Tuesday, with his defense lawyer telling a 12-member jury that the former U.S. president should be acquitted of all 34 charges he is facing that he illegally sought to influence the outcome of the 2016 election that sent him to the White House.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent,\" defense lawyer Todd Blanche declared. \"He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof -- period.\"\n\nBlanche immediately attacked the credibility of the prosecution's key witness, one-time Trump political fixer Michael Cohen, a convicted perjurer who testified during the six-week trial that at Trump's behest he paid $130,000 in hush money just ahead of the election to porn star Stormy Daniels to silence her claim she had a one-night tryst with Trump in 2006.\n\nThe defense lawyer said Trump \"has unequivocally and repeatedly denied\" a liaison with Daniels and said of Cohen's testimony: \"They were lies. Pure and simple.\"\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the words of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said.\n\nThe defense lawyer said he expected his argument before the seven men and five women on the jury to last about 2\u00bd hours. Then, prosecutor Joshua Steinglass gets his turn to try to persuade jurors that they should convict Trump in the first-ever trial of a U.S. president. Steinglass told New York Supreme Court Justice Juan Merchan his arguments could last 4 to 4 1/12 hours.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, Merchan is expected to read legal instructions to the jury and then hand the case to the jurors for their closed-door deliberations.\n\nUnder the U.S. legal system, the jurors will have to unanimously decide whether to acquit the 77-year-old Trump or find him guilty. If they cannot agree, resulting in a hung jury, prosecutors then would decide whether to retry the case.\n\nFor Trump, the outcome is consequential, not only for his personal freedom but his political fate. He is the presumptive 2024 Republican presidential candidate, set to run again in the November election against President Joe Biden, the Democrat who defeated him in 2020.\n\nNational polls show Biden and Trump locked in a tight contest, but some opinion polls indicate Trump supporters could switch their vote to Biden or not vote at all if the former president is convicted.\n\nIf convicted, Trump could be placed on probation or be sentenced to up to four years in prison, although he is certain to appeal and could continue to run for the presidency.\n\nTrump is facing three other indictments, including two accusing him of illegally trying to upend his 2020 election loss. But all three cases are tied up in legal wrangling between his lawyers and prosecutors. As a result, the New York case nearing completion may be the only one decided before the November election.\n\nTrump had often said he wanted to testify in his own defense at the trial, but in the end, did not, which was his right.\n\nProsecutors called 20 witnesses to testify about an array of paperwork showing how Cohen was repaid in 2017 for the hush money he wired to Daniels' lawyers just days before the election.\n\nCohen testified that Trump told him to \"just do it\" -- to send the money to Daniels, and then later twice approved the reimbursement plan, once just before he was inaugurated as the country's 45th president and then again at a White House meeting less than three weeks after he assumed office. Trump's defense team has contended the 2017 payments to Cohen were for legal work he did for Trump, not a hush money reimbursement.\n\nTrump's team put only two witnesses on the stand. One of them, New York lawyer Robert Costello, said that in 2018, Cohen assured him he had \"nothing on Trump\" and that he, not Trump, concocted the hush money payment deal with Daniels.\n\nTrump urged several Republican lawmakers to show up in the courtroom during the trial in the seats behind the defense table as a show of support. The legislators, including House of Representatives Speaker Mike Johnson, often stayed for an hour or two of testimony and then, because they were not subject to the gag order barring Trump from attacking witnesses and jurors, walked outside the courthouse and held news conferences to criticize witnesses against Trump, especially Cohen and Daniels.\n\nSome of Trump's adult children occasionally showed up at the trial, but not his wife, former first lady Melania Trump. His two oldest sons, Donald Trump Jr. and Eric, were there Tuesday, as was his second daughter, Tiffany Trump.\n\nThe question for the jurors centers on Cohen's credibility, and whether the paperwork documents in the case outweigh any doubts they may have about his checkered history.\n\nHe acknowledged during hours of testimony that he has over the years been a serial liar on Trump's behalf and to protect his own wife from tax evasion charges. He said that as part of the hush money reimbursement plan, he stole $60,000 from the Trump company because he felt Trump had shorted him on his year-end 2016 bonus.\n\nCohen testified that with Trump's consent, Allen Weisselberg, the Trump Organization's then-chief financial officer, \"grossed up\" the overall reimbursement to $420,000, in part to cover Cohen's tax liability, and that the reimbursement was paid out in $35,000 monthly increments in 2017, with Trump signing nine of the 11 checks to Cohen.\n\nDespite his pivotal role in the reimbursement, Weisselberg, now serving a five-month prison sentence for lying under oath in a previous Trump-related business fraud civil case, was not called as a witness by the prosecution, which Blanche immediately noted at the start of his closing argument.\n\nEarly witnesses in the trial portrayed Cohen as brash, profane and volatile. However, on the witness stand, the 57-year-old disbarred lawyer was reserved and did not erupt under hours of a withering cross-examination by Blanche.\n\nFor years, Cohen was a Trump loyalist, his lawyer and political fixer who tended to Trump's every whim during his years as a New York real estate magnate and during his 2016 run for the presidency. As news of Daniels' claim of a liaison with Trump and the hush money reimbursement to Cohen became public in 2018, the relationship between the then-president and Cohen ruptured after federal agents raided his then-New York home, a hotel room.\n\nIn the end, Cohen pleaded guilty to perjury in connection with his lying to a congressional panel about a Trump Tower construction project in Moscow that never materialized, tax fraud and a campaign finance law violation linked to the hush money payment to Daniels. He served 13\u00bd months in a federal prison and another year-and-a-half in home confinement.\n\nSince then, he has turned into a persistent Trump critic. He testified pointedly that he hopes Trump is convicted.\n\nThe 45-year-old Daniels testified that Trump invited her to dinner in his hotel suite at a Lake Tahoe golf tourney in the western state of Nevada but never brought in any food. After talking for a while, Daniels said she unexpectedly found Trump sitting in his underwear on his bed when she emerged from a bathroom. Soon thereafter, Daniels said they had sex although she blacked out on the details of it.\n\nA month before the 2016 November election, The Washington Post unearthed a 2005 outtake from the celebrity-driven \"Access Hollywood\" show in which Trump boasted that he could grope women at will because he was a star.\n\nThe emergence of the tape led directly to the hush money payment to Daniels. The Trump campaign was worried that the Access Hollywood footage might offend female voters and that one more sex-related Trump story would be worse. Daniels, at the same time, was hawking her Trump story or wanted money to stay quiet.\n\nCohen said he created a shell company, transferred money into it from his home equity line of credit and wired Daniels' lawyer the hush money. Cohen said he would not have made the payment on his own without Trump's assent.\n\nWithin a week, Trump narrowly defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton, a former first lady and U.S. secretary of state, to win a four-year term in the White House.", "source": {"uri": "voanews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "VOA Voice of America"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8149999243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:24:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:24:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:23:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/trump-is-innocent-defence-lawyer-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-hush-money-trial-1.6903199", "title": "Trump is 'innocent,' defence lawyer tells jury as closing arguments get underway in hush money trial", "body": "Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former U.S. president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" said defence attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defence attorneys will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a US$130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8149998193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:23:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:23:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:22:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/the-latest-defense-lawyer-begins-delivering-closing-arguments-in-trumps-hush-money-case/article_78b9b6f8-c9ab-51b4-87ae-cf2b70c47db1.html", "title": "The Latest | Defense lawyer begins delivering closing arguments in Trump's hush money case", "body": "Former President Donald Trump speaks to his attorney Todd Blanche before the start of proceedings in Manhattan Criminal Court, Tuesday, May 28, 2024, in New York.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Closing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Here's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\n-- As Trump's hush money trial nears end, would-be spectators camp out for days to get inside\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\n-- Trump hush money case: A timeline of key events\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nBIDEN AND TRUMP CAMPAIGNS HOLD DUELING NEWS CONFERENCES OUTSIDE COURTHOUSE\n\nJoe Biden's campaign announced on Tuesday that it would hold an event with \"special guests\" as closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are underway.\n\nTrump spokesman Jason Miller said the former president's allies will respond with their own event immediately following Biden's.\n\nHe posted on the social platform X that Biden's allies \"aren't in PA, MI, WI, NV, AZ or GA -- they're outside the Biden Trial against President Trump,\" adding: \"It's always been about politics.\"\n\nPOWERPOINT CLOSING\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.\n\nDEFENSE BEGINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him.\n\n\"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nMERCHAN EXPLAINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROCESS\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last.\n\nMerchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2\u00bd hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nTHE SCENE IN THE COURTROOM\n\nDonald Trump stood and looked back for a moment after he arrived at the defense table for the start of closing arguments in his hush money trial. Sitting between two of his attorneys -- Todd Blanche and Emil Bove -- the former president appeared animated before the proceedings began, gesturing and chatting with his lawyers.\n\nSeated behind Trump are members of his family, including his sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. and his daughter Tiffany.\n\nTRUMP: IT'S 'A DARK DAY IN AMERICA'\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\"\n\nThe former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said.\n\nHe was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.\n\nTRUMP ARRIVES AT COURTHOUSE\n\nA small of supporters yelled \"We love Trump\" outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning as Donald Trump's motorcade arrived. The supporters waved American flags and were wearing red \"Make America Great Again\" hats.\n\nInside, the prosecution team made its way into the courtroom, led by Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass, who is expected to make the prosecution's closing argument.\n\nAs has been his routine, Steinglass walked in carrying a file box full of papers.\n\nTRUMP FAMILY MEMBERS WILL BE IN COURT\n\nSeveral of Donald Trump's family members plan to be at court Tuesday for his hush money trial.\n\nThey include his sons, Don Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, daughter-in-law Lara Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos.\n\nOther family members have not yet joined him in court, including his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and his eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump.\n\nWHAT HAPPENS DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS?\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will have their final opportunity to address the jury in closing arguments.\n\nThe arguments don't count as evidence in the case charging Donald Trump with falsifying business records to cover up hush money payments during the 2016 presidential election. They'll instead function as hourslong recaps of the key points the lawyers want to leave jurors with before the panel disappears behind closed doors for deliberations.\n\nJurors over the course of a month have heard testimony about sex and bookkeeping, tabloid journalism and presidential politics. Their task ahead will be to decide whether prosecutors who have charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business records have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\nWHAT MUST BE PROVED FOR A CONVICTION?\n\nWith closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial expected to get underway Tuesday morning, jurors have a weighty task ahead of them -- deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of some, all or none of the 34 felony counts he's charged with.\n\nTo convict Trump of felony falsifying business records, prosecutors must convince jurors beyond a reasonable doubt that he not only falsified or caused business records to be entered falsely but also did so with intent to commit or conceal another crime. Any verdict must be unanimous.\n\nTo prevent a conviction, the defense simply needs to convince at least one juror that prosecutors haven't proved Trump's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard for criminal cases.\n\nNew York also has a misdemeanor falsifying business records charge, which requires proving only that a defendant made or caused the false entries, but it is not part of Trump's case and will not be considered by jurors.\n\nA SEAT IN COURT DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROVES ALLURING FOR SOME\n\nFor many Americans, Memorial Day weekend was a moment to remember the sacrifices of U.S. military personnel and to unplug from the bustle of daily life.\n\nFor others, it was a chance to snag a prime spot in line for entry into Donald Trump's hush money trial ahead of Tuesday's closing arguments. Last Friday afternoon saw several people camped out -- including professional line sitters with pup tents -- for a chance to see the tail end of the historic proceedings up close and personal.\n\nThough most of the seats inside the courtroom are reserved for lawyers, members of Trump's entourage, security personnel and journalists, a few are open to the general public.\n\nThe former president's Manhattan trial has drawn visitors from all over, including students from local schools and plenty of out-of-towners.\n\nWHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are expected to begin on Tuesday, marking the beginning of the end of the historic proceedings that kicked off in April.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will make their final pitch to jurors, hoping to sway them in one direction or another after more than four weeks of witness testimony.\n\nFollowing the conclusion of closing arguments, which are expected to last all day, Judge Juan M. Merchan will spend about an hour instructing the jury on the law governing the case, providing a roadmap for what it can and cannot take into account as it evaluates the Republican former president's guilt or innocence.\n\nJurors could begin deliberations as early as Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8149988942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:17:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:17:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:16:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://thedailyrecord.com/2024/05/28/trump-is-innocent-defense-tells-jury-as-closing-arguments-get-underway-in-ny-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Trump is 'innocent,' defense tells jury as closing arguments get underway in NY hush money trial - Maryland Daily Record", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former president told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give attorneys one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" said defense attorney Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of testimony, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent a porn actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough testimony to convict Trump of all charges while defense attorneys will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, likely Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations. The deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centers on a $130,000 payment Cohen made to porn actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite. Trump has denied Daniels' account, and his attorney, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who testified that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying $150,000 to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a yearlong affair with Trump; and Cohen, who testified that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions -- \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal. Trump has denied a relationship with McDougal too.\n\nDefense lawyers called two witnesses -- neither of them Trump. They focused much of their energy on discrediting Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent. Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they won't be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence -- and there were many. Judge Juan M. Merchan, for instance, fined Trump $10,000 for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But it's unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nMichael R. Sisak, Jennifer Peltz, Eric Tucker and Jill Colvin report for The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "thedailyrecord.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Maryland Daily Record"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8150023010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:38:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/news/national/the-latest-defense-lawyer-begins-delivering-closing-arguments-in-trumps-hush-money-case/article_d83905b0-48f4-5abb-9c37-4d55660fbed7.html", "title": "The Latest | Defense lawyer begins delivering closing arguments in Trump's hush money case", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Closing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Here's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\n-- As Trump's hush money trial nears end, would-be spectators camp out for days to get inside\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\n-- Trump hush money case: A timeline of key events\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nBIDEN AND TRUMP CAMPAIGNS HOLD DUELING NEWS CONFERENCES OUTSIDE COURTHOUSE\n\nJoe Biden's campaign announced on Tuesday that it would hold an event with \"special guests\" as closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are underway.\n\nTrump spokesman Jason Miller said the former president's allies will respond with their own event immediately following Biden's.\n\nHe posted on the social platform X that Biden's allies \"aren't in PA, MI, WI, NV, AZ or GA -- they're outside the Biden Trial against President Trump,\" adding: \"It's always been about politics.\"\n\nPOWERPOINT CLOSING\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.\n\nDEFENSE BEGINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him.\n\n\"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nMERCHAN EXPLAINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROCESS\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last.\n\nMerchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2\u00bd hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nTHE SCENE IN THE COURTROOM\n\nDonald Trump stood and looked back for a moment after he arrived at the defense table for the start of closing arguments in his hush money trial. Sitting between two of his attorneys -- Todd Blanche and Emil Bove -- the former president appeared animated before the proceedings began, gesturing and chatting with his lawyers.\n\nSeated behind Trump are members of his family, including his sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. and his daughter Tiffany.\n\nTRUMP: IT'S 'A DARK DAY IN AMERICA'\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\"\n\nThe former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said.\n\nHe was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.\n\nTRUMP ARRIVES AT COURTHOUSE\n\nA small of supporters yelled \"We love Trump\" outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning as Donald Trump's motorcade arrived. The supporters waved American flags and were wearing red \"Make America Great Again\" hats.\n\nInside, the prosecution team made its way into the courtroom, led by Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass, who is expected to make the prosecution's closing argument.\n\nAs has been his routine, Steinglass walked in carrying a file box full of papers.\n\nTRUMP FAMILY MEMBERS WILL BE IN COURT\n\nSeveral of Donald Trump's family members plan to be at court Tuesday for his hush money trial.\n\nThey include his sons, Don Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, daughter-in-law Lara Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos.\n\nOther family members have not yet joined him in court, including his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and his eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump.\n\nWHAT HAPPENS DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS?\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will have their final opportunity to address the jury in closing arguments.\n\nThe arguments don't count as evidence in the case charging Donald Trump with falsifying business records to cover up hush money payments during the 2016 presidential election. They'll instead function as hourslong recaps of the key points the lawyers want to leave jurors with before the panel disappears behind closed doors for deliberations.\n\nJurors over the course of a month have heard testimony about sex and bookkeeping, tabloid journalism and presidential politics. Their task ahead will be to decide whether prosecutors who have charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business records have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\nWHAT MUST BE PROVED FOR A CONVICTION?\n\nWith closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial expected to get underway Tuesday morning, jurors have a weighty task ahead of them -- deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of some, all or none of the 34 felony counts he's charged with.\n\nTo convict Trump of felony falsifying business records, prosecutors must convince jurors beyond a reasonable doubt that he not only falsified or caused business records to be entered falsely but also did so with intent to commit or conceal another crime. Any verdict must be unanimous.\n\nTo prevent a conviction, the defense simply needs to convince at least one juror that prosecutors haven't proved Trump's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard for criminal cases.\n\nNew York also has a misdemeanor falsifying business records charge, which requires proving only that a defendant made or caused the false entries, but it is not part of Trump's case and will not be considered by jurors.\n\nA SEAT IN COURT DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROVES ALLURING FOR SOME\n\nFor many Americans, Memorial Day weekend was a moment to remember the sacrifices of U.S. military personnel and to unplug from the bustle of daily life.\n\nFor others, it was a chance to snag a prime spot in line for entry into Donald Trump's hush money trial ahead of Tuesday's closing arguments. Last Friday afternoon saw several people camped out -- including professional line sitters with pup tents -- for a chance to see the tail end of the historic proceedings up close and personal.\n\nThough most of the seats inside the courtroom are reserved for lawyers, members of Trump's entourage, security personnel and journalists, a few are open to the general public.\n\nThe former president's Manhattan trial has drawn visitors from all over, including students from local schools and plenty of out-of-towners.\n\nWHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are expected to begin on Tuesday, marking the beginning of the end of the historic proceedings that kicked off in April.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will make their final pitch to jurors, hoping to sway them in one direction or another after more than four weeks of witness testimony.\n\nFollowing the conclusion of closing arguments, which are expected to last all day, Judge Juan M. Merchan will spend about an hour instructing the jury on the law governing the case, providing a roadmap for what it can and cannot take into account as it evaluates the Republican former president's guilt or innocence.\n\nJurors could begin deliberations as early as Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8150286638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:45:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:45:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:44:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/national/24350704.key-witness-lied-donald-trumps-lawyer-tells-jurors-closing-arguments/", "title": "Key witness lied, Donald Trump's lawyer tells jurors during closing arguments", "body": "The closing arguments, which were expected to last the entire day, gave lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\".\n\nIn an hours-long address to the jury, Mr Blanche attacked the foundation of the case, which charges Trump with conspiring to conceal hush money payments prosecutors say were made on his behalf during the 2016 presidential campaign to stifle an adult film actress's claim that she had a sexual encounter with Trump a decade earlier.\n\nWith sweeping denials mirroring his client's \"deny everything\" approach, Mr Blanche countered the prosecution's portrayal of Trump as a detail-oriented manager who paid dutiful attention to the cheques he signed; disputed the contention that Trump and the adult film actress, Stormy Daniels, had sex; and rejected the idea that the alleged hush money scheme amounted to illegal interference in the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win,\" Mr Blanche said.\n\nAfter more than four weeks of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with the payments.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyerss aimed to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen.\n\nTrump's former lawyer and personal fixer pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\n\"He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly,\" Mr Blanche said of Mr Cohen.\n\n\"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates.\"\n\nAfter closing arguments, the judge will instruct the jury on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to Ms Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels.\n\nTrump's lawyers contended throughout the trial that they were legitimate payments for actual legal services.\n\nMr Blanche, delivering a PowerPoint presentation to jurors, pointed to emails and evidence showing that Mr Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Mr Cohen characterised that work as \"very minimal\", Mr Blanche argued otherwise.\n\nThe lawyer's voice became even more impassioned as he revisited one of the more memorable moments of the trial: when Mr Blanche sought to unravel Mr Cohen's claim that he had spoken to Trump by phone about the Daniels arrangement on October 24 2016.\n\nMr Cohen said he had contacted Trump's bodyguard as a way of getting hold of Trump, but Mr Blanche asserted that at the time Mr Cohen was actually dealing with a spate of harassing phone calls and was preoccupied by that problem.\n\nMr Blanche also sought to distance Trump from the mechanics of the reimbursements, saying cheques to Mr Cohen were signed as Trump was preoccupied with the presidency in 2017.\n\nHe pointed to the evidence of a former Trump Organisation controller, who told jurors that he never talked to Trump about how to characterise the payments sent to an accounts payable staffer.\n\nMr Blanche also noted that another Trump aide said Trump would sign cheques while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions.\n\n\"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to former Playboy model Karen McDougal to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nIt is unclear if any of the others will reach trial before November's election.",
