{"uri": "8150350813", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:38:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:38:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:38:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.dailycamera.com/2024/05/28/judge-scolds-trump-lawyer-for-outrageous-comments-in-closing-about-trumps-prison-threat/", "title": "Judge scolds Trump lawyer for 'outrageous' comments in closing about Trump's prison threat", "body": "By MOLLY CRANE-NEWMAN and JOSEPHINE STRATMAN, New York Daily News\n\nJustice Juan Merchan scolded Donald Trump's attorney Todd Blanche for improperly invoking the threat of prison time facing the former president toward the end of the defense's summation at the historic hush money trial.\n\n\"It's simply not allowed. Period,\" the judge boomed, saying Blanche should have known better as a former prosecutor and longtime defense attorney.\n\n\"It's hard for me to imagine how that was accidental in any way.\"\n\nBlanche brought up the possibility Trump could go to prison toward the end of his summation.\n\nCalling Blanche's comment \"outrageous,\" the judge granted a request from prosecutors to instruct jurors to disregard it.\n\nHere's the latest in live updates from the courtroom:\n\nBlanche addressed one of the prosecution's most pivotal pieces of evidence: A First Republic Bank statement reflecting lawyer Michael Cohen's payment to adult film actress Stormy Daniels' lawyer, which prosecutors say was meant to buy the porn star's silence about an alleged sexual tryst with Trump.\n\nThe statement includes handwritten notes from Trump Org CFO Allen Weisselberg calculating how much Cohen was owed for the transaction and other expenses.\n\nBlanche zeroed in on Cohen's notes on the right side of the page, which said he was owed $50,000 for paying a tech company. Cohen admitted during his testimony that he'd actually paid $20,000 for the expense.\n\n\"The point of this document is it contains lies,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche, threw everything he could at the wall to undercut the prosecution's monthlong case against Trump, taking shots at Cohen, Daniels, her former lawyer Keith Davidson, and asking jurors to question why they didn't hear from other critical players like Weisselberg.\n\nLaunching into the 34 criminal counts -- encompassing the checks, ledger entries, and invoices recording Trump's 2017 payments to Cohen -- Blanche said Trump wasn't connected to any of them.\n\nHe said Trump was busy leading the nation when he signed the checks presented to him, that the invoices were Cohen's handiwork, and that his company dealt with the rest.\n\nBlanche accused Cohen of lying about Trump knowing he paid off Daniels, claiming Trump's anxious fixer went rogue, hoping it would earn him brownie points with Trump down the line. He also accused Cohen of lying about no verbal agreement with Trump to be his personal lawyer after winning the White House.\n\nBlanche said the jury shouldn't convict Trump just because the prosecution showed that Trump was fastidious about his finances: \"You can't convict President Trump because sometimes ... [he] looked at invoices, that somehow he had full knowledge of what was happening.\"\n\nDiving into the alleged conspiracy to defraud the electorate with a \"catch and kill\" scheme, Blanche said none existed and that Trump was too \"sophisticated\" to genuinely believe stories in the National Enquirer would influence the election.\n\n\"Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to elect a candidate,\" Blanche said, arguing that Trump's actions were routine.\n\nTrump sat sideways, arm slung over the back of his chair, appearing to pay close attention as Blanche spoke.\n\n\"You should want and expect more than the testimony of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said as he began his summation, rattling off other witnesses who took the stand against his client, including Daniels and Davidson, who he then accused of extortion.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump -- you cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt based on the words of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the DA has not met their burden of proof. Period.\"\n\nAfter a weeklong hiatus, both sides will spend the day in Manhattan Supreme Court court making their final pleas to the panel of New Yorkers, who will soon return to the jury room to decide the outcome of the historic case.\n\nBy New York law, Trump's side is presenting their summation first, which the GOP frontrunner blasted as a conspiracy in a string of Memorial Day Truth Social posts.\n\nAfter jurors hear final arguments from both sides, Merchan will instruct them on the law and how to deliberate the case.\n\nTrump walked into court at 9:25 a.m. -- for the first time, joined by both of his older sons, Eric and Don Jr., his youngest daughter, Tiffany Trump, an army of lawyers, and various allies and campaign staffers. {"uri": "8150068871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "15:12:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T15:12:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:09:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13468105/Donald-Trump-innocent-defence-lawyer-tells-jury-closing-arguments-begin.html", "title": "Donald Trump is innocent, defence lawyer tells jury as closing...", "body": "Donald Trump is \"innocent\" and did not break the law, a lawyer for the former US president has told jurors during closing arguments as the landmark hush money trial moved closer to its conclusion.\n\nThe arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" in the witness box and cannot be trusted.\n\nDonald Trump appears at Manhattan Criminal Court before closing arguments in his criminal hush money trial in New York (Spencer Platt/Pool Photo via AP)\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Mr Blanche said.\n\n\"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent an adult film actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyers will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, probably on Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nThe deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nFormer US president Donald Trump at Manhattan Criminal Court (Spencer Platt/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nFormer US president Donald Trump at Manhattan Criminal Court before closing arguments in his criminal hush money trial (Spencer Platt/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments on Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions - \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nMichael Cohen (Seth Wenig/AP)\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they will not be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence - and there were many.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan, for instance, fined Trump 10,000 dollars (\u00a37,800) for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nDonald Trump speaks to members of the media upon arriving at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York (Julia Nikhinson, Pool/AP)\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election.\n\nBut it is unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8150279279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:41:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:41:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:38:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/the-latest-defense-ends-its-summation-in-hush-money-case-implores-jury-to-find-trump/article_78b9b6f8-c9ab-51b4-87ae-cf2b70c47db1.html", "title": "The Latest | Defense ends its summation in hush money case, implores jury to find Trump 'not guilty'", "body": "Robert De Niro, center, argues with a Donald Trump supporter after speaking to reporters in support of President Joe Biden across the street from Trump's criminal trial in New York, Tuesday, May 28, 2024.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Closing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche said he expected to speak for about 2 1/2 hours while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he might go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Here's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\n-- As Trump's hush money trial nears end, would-be spectators camp out for days to get inside\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\n-- Trump hush money case: A timeline of key events\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nDEFENSE IMPLORES JURY TO RETURN A 'NOT GUILTY' VERDICT\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche finished his summation Tuesday by telling jurors the hush money case \"isn't a referendum on your views of President Trump.\"\n\n\"This is not a referendum on the ballot box -- who you voted for in 2016 or 2020, who you plan on voting for in 2024. That is not what this is about,\" the attorney told jurors. \"The verdict you have to reach has to do with the evidence you heard in this courtroom,\" and nothing else, he reminds them.\n\nHe implored the jury to return a quick \"not guilty\" verdict.\n\nBLANCHE CALLS COHEN 'AN MVP OF LIARS'\n\nAs he neared the end of his summation on Tuesday, defense lawyer Todd Blanche reminded jurors of Michael Cohen's admitted fixation on Donald Trump -- and his desire to see him behind bars.\n\nBlanche played short clips of Cohen's podcast in which he commended District Attorney Alvin Bragg and said that the idea of seeing the former president booked on criminal charges \"fills me with delight.\"\n\nThe case against Trump is built around testimony from \"a witness that outright hates the defendant, wants him in jail, is actively making money off that hatred,\" Blanche said.\n\nWhile Cohen has testified that he lied to protect Trump, his family and others, Blanche asserted that the ex-lawyer \"is lying simply to protect Michael Cohen and nobody else. Period.\"\n\nBlanche's voice grew to a roar -- the loudest he had been all morning -- as he also declared that Cohen had lied about speaking to Trump by phone about the Stormy Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche called Cohen \"literally like an MVP of liars.\"\n\n\"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates,\" he said.\n\nDEFENSE SHARPENS CRITIQUE OF 'CATCH AND KILLS'\n\nTrump lawyer Todd Blanche on Tuesday questioned the prosecution's narrative that the Stormy Daniels payment in October 2016 was part of a conspiracy amongst Trump, Michael Cohen and the National Enquirer to suppress negative stories about the then-candidate through the practice known as \"catch and kill.\"\n\nCohen had known about Daniels' claim since it was published without her permission on a gossip website in 2011, Blanche said, adding that Daniels had authorized her manager to seek offers to sell the story in early 2016.\n\n\"Why did it not go anywhere for months and months and months if there was a catch-and-kill scheme?\" Blanche asked.\n\nCohen agreed to pay Daniels in the final weeks of the 2016 presidential campaign, after the leak of the \"Access Hollywood\" tape.\n\nBlanche reminded jurors of the two other stories prosecutors say were buried through \"catch and kill.\"\n\nThe National Enquirer paid $30,000 for a since-disproven rumor from a Trump Tower doorman and $150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal for her claim of an affair with Trump, though publisher David Pecker testified the tabloid wasn't interested in pursuing her story at first because it couldn't be corroborated.\n\nPecker said he refused to pay Daniels because he didn't want to shell out any more money for Trump without getting repaid, leaving Cohen to make the deal himself.\n\nBlanche suggested the publisher didn't want anything to do with the story anyway.\n\n\"That's our conspiracy? That's the three catch and kills?\" Blanche said.\n\nDEFENSE TRIES TO DOWNPLAY 'ACCESS HOLLYWOOD' TAPE\n\nLawyer Todd Blanche tried on Tuesday to downplay the fallout from the \"Access Hollywood\" tape that sent Donald Trump's 2016 campaign into a tailspin, telling the jury: \"It was not a doomsday event.\"\n\nBlanche conceded in his summation that Trump was bothered by the story. \"Nobody wants their family to be subjected to that type of thing,\" he said. \"It doesn't matter if you're running for office, if you're running 'The Apprentice' ... Nobody wants their family exposed to that type of story.\"\n\nNonetheless, he argued characterizations of the tape as devastating were an exaggeration. He pointed to testimony from Trump's former assistant Madeleine Westerhout, whom he said cast the fallout as \"a couple of days of frustration and consternation.\"\n\nWesterhout, who was then working for the Republican National Committee in close coordination with the Trump campaign, had testified that the tape \"rattled the RNC leadership\" but that Trump wasn't thrown by it.\n\nReince Priebus, then-chair of the Republican National Committee, had told Trump after the tape was released that he had two choices: drop out of the race or lose by the largest margin in history, Trump's former chief strategist Steve Bannon has recounted.\n\nBLANCHE ARGUES 'PEOPLE ALREADY KNEW' ABOUT DANIELS' CLAIMS\n\nTurning to Stormy Daniels' story, defense lawyer Todd Blanche noted in his summation that her allegations of a 2006 sexual encounter with Donald Trump were aired on a gossip site in 2011 -- four years before Trump announced his presidential candidacy. Trump has denied having sex with Daniels.\n\n\"So how could this issue have influenced the election?\" Blanche argued. \"People already knew about the allegations.\"\n\nAt the behest of Daniels and Michael Cohen, the story was taken off the site.\n\nBlanche asserted that the real impetus behind Daniels' interest in making a deal in 2016 was that some people wanted to use the election as pressure to \"extort\" Trump.\n\nFollowing a brief morning break, Blanche singled out that Daniels issued two statements in 2018 denying that she'd ever had a sexual encounter with Trump. She testified earlier in the hush money trial that she signed off on them at her lawyer's urging.\n\nDEFENSE DENIES RECORDED CONVERSATION WAS ABOUT PAYOFF OF FORMER MODEL\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche spotlighted a key piece of prosecution evidence during his summation: the secret recording Michael Cohen says he made of himself briefing Donald Trump on a plan to buy the rights to former Playboy model Karen McDougal's story from the National Enquirer.\n\nBlanche said the September 2016 recording, which cuts off before the conversation finishes, is unreliable and was actually about a plan to buy a collection of material on Trump that the National Enquirer had been hoarding -- not McDougal. Cohen has said the audio cut off because the iPhone he was using to make the recording was receiving a phone call.\n\n\"There is no doubt that this recording discussed AMI and discussed Mr. Pecker,\" Blanche said, referring to the National Enquirer's parent company and then-publisher. \"There is a lot of doubt that it discussed Karen McDougal.\"\n\nAfter playing parts of the recording, Blanche urged jurors to trust their ears when deciphering a specific part -- whether Trump mentioned a dollar figure that he might have to spend, as Cohen and prosecutors contend, or whether he said something else.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump said, according to Cohen and prosecutors, as in $150,000.\n\n\"Listen to the recording. See if you hear one-fifty,\" Blanche told jurors.\n\nTRUMP CAMPAIGN HOLDS ITS OWN NEWS CONFERENCE\n\nDonald Trump's campaign staffers held their own news conference outside the courthouse Tuesday morning in the exact same spot where actor Robert De Niro and Jan. 6 officers had just spoken on behalf of Joe Biden's campaign.\n\nJason Miller, Trump's senior campaign advisor, called De Niro \"a washed-up actor,\" and said the news conference showed that the hush money trial was political.\n\n\"After months of saying politics had nothing to do with this trial, they showed up and made a campaign event out of a lower Manhattan trial day for President Trump,\" Miller said.\n\nKaroline Leavitt, the campaign press secretary, called the Biden campaign \"desperate and failing\" and \"pathetic\" and said their event outside the trial was \"a full-blown concession that this trial is a witch hunt that comes from the top.\"\n\nBLANCHE: 'THIS WASN'T A CATCH AND KILL'\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's hush money trial took issue on Tuesday with the notion that there was a conspiracy to suppress negative stories to help Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to American Media Inc.'s $30,000 payment to Dino Sajudin, a former Trump Tower doorman who falsely alleged the former president had fathered a child out of wedlock. It was one of three potentially damaging stories about Trump the tabloid did not run.\n\nBlanche then pointed to former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker's testimony that he saw the doorman story as a potential blockbuster and would gladly have published it if it had been true.\n\n\"This isn't a catch and kill. This is an opportunity,\" Blanche said. \"It was worth too much to catch and kill, full stop.\"\n\nHe also noted Pecker had testified that the tabloid only published about half the stories they purchased.\n\n\"That's meaningful. That matters,\" Blanche told the jury.\n\nHe later targeted prosecutors' portrayal of Karen McDougal's deal with AMI as part of the purported hush money conspiracy, emphasizing testimony from her lawyer and others that she didn't want her claim published.\n\nRather, Blanche said, the former Playboy model wanted to reenergize her career by getting into magazines, according to the testimony -- though McDougal herself didn't testify.\n\n\"This was not a catch-and-kill,\" Blanche said.\n\nDE NIRO: TRUMP IS A THREAT TO DEMOCRACY\n\nRobert De Niro said Tuesday morning that presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump does not belong in the White House. The actor was campaigning for President Joe Biden in lower Manhattan, joined by former law enforcement officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.\n\nThey stood not far from where closing arguments were happening in Trump's criminal hush money trial. Trump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nDe Niro said if Trump returns to the White House, Americans can \"kiss these freedoms goodbye that we all take for granted.\"\n\nBLANCHE URGES JURORS TO DISREGARD 'CONSPIRACY' CONCERNS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche implored the jury in Donald Trump's criminal trial to reject the prosecution's contention that he engaged in a conspiracy to influence the 2016 election by involving himself in efforts to bury negative stories about him -- and to reject the allegation that, after the fact, he falsified records of Michael Cohen's payments to hide that conspiracy.\n\n\"The government wants you to believe that President Trump did these things with his records to conceal efforts to promote his successful candidacy in 2016, the year before,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"Even that, even if you find that is true, that is not enough ... it doesn't matter if there's a conspiracy to win an election. Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win.\"\n\nDEFENSE SAYS TRUMP WATCHES HIS FINANCE CAREFULLY\n\nAfter arguing earlier Tuesday that Donald Trump may not have been fully aware of all his invoices, defense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed to jurors that the former president was a stickler about watching his finances.\n\nMichael Cohen received $420,000 in all from Trump in 2017, a sum that the ex-lawyer and prosecutors in the former president's hush money case have said included the $130,000 reimbursement related to Stormy Daniels, a $50,000 repayment for an unrelated expense and a $60,000 bonus. On top of that, prosecutors have said, there was extra money to cover taxes that would be due on the $130,000 as income -- taxes that wouldn't apply if it had simply been paid as a business expense reimbursement.\n\n\"That is absurd,\" Blanche told jurors, pointing to \"all the other evidence you heard about how carefully President Trump watches his finances.\"\n\nACTOR ROBERT DE NIRO AND JAN. 6 FIRST RESPONDERS SPEAK NEAR TRUMP'S TRIAL\n\nBiden campaign deploys actor Robert De Niro, Jan. 6 first responders near Trump's trial\n\nJoe Biden's campaign sent actor Robert De Niro and two law enforcement officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 to an area in lower Manhattan not far from the criminal court where Donald Trump's hush money trial is happening.\n\nSpeaking while the former president was stuck in court, De Niro said Trump wants to \"destroy not only the city but the country and eventually he could destroy the world.\"\n\nAs he spoke, Trump protesters screamed anti-Biden chants.\n\nTRUMP WAS EXTREMELY BUSY WHEN SIGNING CHECKS, BLANCHE SAYS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed during his summation on Tuesday that Donald Trump was busy during the time when he signed the checks at the heart of the hush money case.\n\n\"It matters where President Trump was,\" Blanche said.\n\nHe noted Trump assistant Madeleine Westerhout had testified that the then-president would sometimes sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nBlanche argued it was unreasonable to suggest Trump was aware of the details of every invoice just because he knew of some. \"That is a stretch and that is reasonable doubt, ladies and gentlemen,\" he said.\n\nBLANCHE CRITICIZES PROSECUTIONS USE OF TRUMP'S BOOKS AND MORE\n\nAbout an hour into the defense's closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche took aim at the prosecution's use of excerpts from Trump's books to attempt to portray him as a detail-oriented micromanager who would be fully aware of any money his company was spending.\n\nThe books were from a decade ago, if not older, and were written with the help of ghostwriters, Blanche told the jury.\n\n\"You should be suspicious. That's a red flag,\" Blanche said in an effort to pre-empt the prosecution's closing.\n\nBlanche then started digging into the details of how payments to Michael Cohen were made, first through a trust set up to hold Trump's assets while he was in the White House, then through Trump's personal bank account with checks signed by the then-president.\n\n\"This was a very confusing time for the Trump Organization,\" Blanche said. There were a lot of adjustments being made as Trump's assets were put under the trust's control and it was the first time in decades that Trump wasn't in charge, he added.\n\nAt one point, early in the repayment process in 2017, the then-Trump Organization finance chief emailed a subordinate that it was OK to pay Cohen out of the trust per an agreement with Trump's sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr., who were running the Trump Organization's day-to-day operations at the time. Both were in court on Tuesday.\n\nBlanche questioned why, if prosecutors allege Trump was involved in a conspiracy to conceal the nature of the payments, the sons he put in charge of his company weren't called to the witness stand.\n\nCOHEN WAS TRUMP'S PERSONAL ATTORNEY, BLANCHE REITERATES\n\nA key part of prosecutors' claims in Donald Trump's hush money case is that his former lawyer Michael Cohen wasn't being paid for legal work in 2017, but rather was being reimbursed in a veiled way for the Stormy Daniels payment.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to emails and testimony Tuesday showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche noted that Cohen went on TV to discuss his role as Trump's personal lawyer and put the title in the signature block of every email he sent.\n\n\"This was not a secret. Michael Cohen was President Trump's personal attorney. Period,\" he said.\n\nBIDEN AND TRUMP CAMPAIGNS HOLD DUELING NEWS CONFERENCES OUTSIDE COURTHOUSE\n\nJoe Biden's campaign announced on Tuesday that it would hold an event with \"special guests\" as closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are underway.\n\nTrump spokesman Jason Miller said the former president's allies will respond with their own event immediately following Biden's.\n\nHe posted on the social platform X that Biden's allies \"aren't in PA, MI, WI, NV, AZ or GA -- they're outside the Biden Trial against President Trump,\" adding: \"It's always been about politics.\"\n\nPOWERPOINT CLOSING\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.\n\nDEFENSE BEGINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him.\n\n\"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nMERCHAN EXPLAINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROCESS\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last.\n\nMerchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2\u00bd hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nTHE SCENE IN THE COURTROOM\n\nDonald Trump stood and looked back for a moment after he arrived at the defense table for the start of closing arguments in his hush money trial. Sitting between two of his attorneys -- Todd Blanche and Emil Bove -- the former president appeared animated before the proceedings began, gesturing and chatting with his lawyers.\n\nSeated behind Trump are members of his family, including his sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. and his daughter Tiffany.\n\nTRUMP: IT'S 'A DARK DAY IN AMERICA'\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\"\n\nThe former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said.\n\nHe was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.\n\nTRUMP ARRIVES AT COURTHOUSE\n\nA small of supporters yelled \"We love Trump\" outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning as Donald Trump's motorcade arrived. The supporters waved American flags and were wearing red \"Make America Great Again\" hats.\n\nInside, the prosecution team made its way into the courtroom, led by Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass, who is expected to make the prosecution's closing argument.\n\nAs has been his routine, Steinglass walked in carrying a file box full of papers.\n\nTRUMP FAMILY MEMBERS WILL BE IN COURT\n\nSeveral of Donald Trump's family members plan to be at court Tuesday for his hush money trial.\n\nThey include his sons, Don Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, daughter-in-law Lara Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos.\n\nOther family members have not yet joined him in court, including his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and his eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump.\n\nWHAT HAPPENS DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS?\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will have their final opportunity to address the jury in closing arguments.\n\nThe arguments don't count as evidence in the case charging Donald Trump with falsifying business records to cover up hush money payments during the 2016 presidential election. They'll instead function as hourslong recaps of the key points the lawyers want to leave jurors with before the panel disappears behind closed doors for deliberations.\n\nJurors over the course of a month have heard testimony about sex and bookkeeping, tabloid journalism and presidential politics. Their task ahead will be to decide whether prosecutors who have charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business records have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\nWHAT MUST BE PROVED FOR A CONVICTION?\n\nWith closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial expected to get underway Tuesday morning, jurors have a weighty task ahead of them -- deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of some, all or none of the 34 felony counts he's charged with.\n\nTo convict Trump of felony falsifying business records, prosecutors must convince jurors beyond a reasonable doubt that he not only falsified or caused business records to be entered falsely but also did so with intent to commit or conceal another crime. Any verdict must be unanimous.\n\nTo prevent a conviction, the defense simply needs to convince at least one juror that prosecutors haven't proved Trump's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard for criminal cases.\n\nNew York also has a misdemeanor falsifying business records charge, which requires proving only that a defendant made or caused the false entries, but it is not part of Trump's case and will not be considered by jurors.\n\nA SEAT IN COURT DURING CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROVES ALLURING FOR SOME\n\nFor many Americans, Memorial Day weekend was a moment to remember the sacrifices of U.S. military personnel and to unplug from the bustle of daily life.\n\nFor others, it was a chance to snag a prime spot in line for entry into Donald Trump's hush money trial ahead of Tuesday's closing arguments. Last Friday afternoon saw several people camped out -- including professional line sitters with pup tents -- for a chance to see the tail end of the historic proceedings up close and personal.\n\nThough most of the seats inside the courtroom are reserved for lawyers, members of Trump's entourage, security personnel and journalists, a few are open to the general public.\n\nThe former president's Manhattan trial has drawn visitors from all over, including students from local schools and plenty of out-of-towners.\n\nWHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are expected to begin on Tuesday, marking the beginning of the end of the historic proceedings that kicked off in April.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will make their final pitch to jurors, hoping to sway them in one direction or another after more than four weeks of witness testimony.\n\nFollowing the conclusion of closing arguments, which are expected to last all day, Judge Juan M. Merchan will spend about an hour instructing the jury on the law governing the case, providing a roadmap for what it can and cannot take into account as it evaluates the Republican former president's guilt or innocence.\n\nJurors could begin deliberations as early as Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/trump-defense-attorney-tells-hush-money-jury-to-acquit/", "title": "Trump defense attorney tells hush money jury to acquit | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "Defense lawyers in Donald Trump's hush money trial made their final pitch to the jury on Tuesday, calling for acquittal and insisting the first ever criminal prosecution of a former US president was based on \"lies.\"\n\nLess than six months before American voters choose whether to return Trump to the White House, the stakes riding on the verdict are hard to overstate -- for the 77-year-old personally, but also for the country.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying business records to reimburse his former lawyer Michael Cohen for a $130,000 payment to porn star Stormy Daniels, when her account of a 2006 sexual encounter could have doomed his 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nTrump's attorney Todd Blanche, delivering his closing argument, told the jury that the trial \"isn't a referendum on your views of president Trump\" or \"who you plan on voting for in 2024.\"\n\nProsecutors had failed to prove their case beyond a reasonable doubt, Blanche said, and the only outcome should be a \"very quick and easy not guilty verdict.\"\n\n\"President Trump is innocent,\" he said.\n\nBlanche spent much of his summation attacking Cohen, the prosecution's star witness, who has spent time in prison for tax evasion and other crimes, calling him the \"MVP of liars\" consumed by \"outright hatred for Trump.\"\n\n\"He's literally the greatest liar of all time,\" he said.\n\n\"He told you a number of things on that witness stand that were lies, pure and simple.\n\n\"You cannot convict president Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen.\"\n\nBlanche said Trump was \"busy running the country\" when the reimbursements were made to Cohen and he did not closely inspect all the invoices that came across his desk.\n\n\"There was no intent to defraud and beyond that there was no conspiracy to influence the 2016 election by president Trump,\" Blanche said. \"He did not commit any crimes.\"\n\n- Graphic testimony -\n\nTrump had a grave look on his face as his lawyer spoke, his head titled to the side studying the jurors. He raised his left hand in a fist as he left the courtroom for lunch but did not address the assembled media.\n\nSpeaking to reporters earlier before entering the Manhattan courtroom, Trump said \"this is a very dangerous day for America.\"\n\n\"We have a rigged court case that should have never been brought,\" he said as three of his five children -- Don Jr, Eric and Tiffany -- stood behind him.\n\nProsecutors will get the last word. They will lay out the case that Trump falsified records to keep the hush money payment secret amid fear that the episode could sink his already rocky outsider's bid to defeat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThe 12 jurors -- whose identities have been kept secret for their protection -- will start deliberations as early as Wednesday.\n\nPolls show Trump neck and neck against President Joe Biden in the White House race and the verdict will inject new tension into an already bitter contest.\n\nSpeaking on behalf of the Biden campaign outside court, actor Robert De Niro berated Trump as a \"clown\" and \"grubby real estate developer\" intent on destroying the country.\n\nTrump is the first former or sitting president under criminal indictment, with charges ranging from the relatively minor hush money case to accusations that he took top secret documents and tried to overthrow the 2020 election.\n\nThe New York case, which featured more than 20 witnesses over five weeks and days of gripping testimony by Daniels and Cohen, is the only one likely to come to trial by election day on November 5.\n\nIf convicted, Trump faces up to four years in prison on each of 34 counts, but legal experts say that as a first-time offender he is unlikely to get jail time.\n\nA conviction would not bar him from appearing on the ballot in November.\n\n- Unanimity required -\n\nTrump chose not to testify in his defense -- a move that would have exposed him to damaging cross-examination.\n\nInstead, he used his daily trips to court to stage televised tirades against \"corrupt\" Judge Juan Merchan, and to claim the trial is a Democratic ploy to keep him off the campaign trail.\n\nA number of Republican Trump loyalists, including several vying to be his vice president, have made the trek to the courtroom to sit behind him.\n\nTo return a guilty or not guilty verdict requires the jury to be unanimous. Just one holdout means a hung jury and a mistrial, although prosecutors could seek a new trial.\n\nIn addition to the New York case, Trump has been indicted in Washington and Georgia on charges of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election.\n\nHe also faces charges in Florida of hoarding huge quantities of classified documents after leaving the White House.\n\nbur/cl/sms\n\nFOX41 {"uri": "8150035008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:47:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:47:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:46:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/national/24350704.donald-trump-innocent-defence-lawyer-tells-jury-closing-arguments-begin/", "title": "Donald Trump is innocent, defence lawyer tells jury as closing arguments begin", "body": "The arguments, expected to last the entire day, will give lawyers one last chance to address the Manhattan jury and to score final points with the panel before it starts deliberating the fate of the first former American president to be charged with felony crimes.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof, period,\" said defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who said the evidence in the case should \"leave you wanting\" and that the prosecution's star witness told \"lies\" in the witness box and cannot be trusted.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks\" are simple, Mr Blanche said.\n\n\"A not guilty verdict, period.\"\n\nAfter more than four weeks of evidence, the summations tee up a momentous and historically unprecedented task for the jury as it decides whether to convict the presumptive Republican presidential nominee in connection with payments during the 2016 election to prevent an adult film actor from going public with her claims of a sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nBecause prosecutors have the burden of proof in the case, they will deliver their arguments last.\n\nProsecutors will tell jurors that they have heard enough evidence to convict Trump of all charges while defence lawyers will aim to create doubts about the strength of the evidence by targeting the credibility of Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges for his role in the hush money payments and who served as the star prosecution witness in the trial.\n\nAfter closing arguments are given, the judge will instruct the jury, probably on Wednesday, on the law governing the case and the factors the panel can take into account during deliberations.\n\nThe deliberations will then proceed in secret, though some clues as to the jury's thinking may arrive through any notes it sends to the judge with questions.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty and denied any wrongdoing.\n\nIt is unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment if asked.\n\nThe case centres on a 130,000 dollar (\u00a3101,000) payment Mr Cohen made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels in the final days of the 2016 election to prevent her from going public with her story of a sexual encounter she says she had with Trump 10 years earlier in a Lake Tahoe hotel suite.\n\nTrump has denied Ms Daniels' account, and his lawyer, during hours of questioning in the trial, accused her of making it up.\n\nWhen Trump reimbursed Mr Cohen, the payments were logged as being for legal services, which prosecutors say was designed to conceal the true purpose of the transaction with Ms Daniels and to illegally interfere in the 2016 election, in which Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nTrump's lawyers contend they were legitimate payments for actual legal services, and they say that his celebrity status, particularly during the campaign, made him a target for extortion, points they are expected to revisit during their closing arguments on Tuesday.\n\nThe nearly two dozen witnesses included Ms Daniels, who described in sometimes vivid detail the encounter she says she had with Trump; David Pecker, the former publisher of the National Enquirer, who said that he used his media enterprise to protect Trump by squelching stories that could harm his campaign, including by paying 150,000 dollars (\u00a3117,000) to a former Playboy model to keep her from going public with a claim that she had had a year-long affair with Trump; and Mr Cohen, who said that Trump was intimately involved in the hush money discussions - \"Just pay it,\" the now-disbarred lawyer quoted Trump as saying.\n\nProsecutors are expected to remind jurors of the bank statements, emails and other documentary evidence they have viewed, as well as an audio recording in which Mr Cohen and Trump can be heard discussing the deal involving the Playboy model, Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump has denied a relationship with Ms McDougal too.\n\nDefence lawyers called two witnesses - neither of them Trump.\n\nThey focused much of their energy on discrediting Mr Cohen, pressing him on his own criminal history, his past lies and his recollection of key details.\n\nOn cross-examination, for instance, Mr Cohen admitted stealing tens of thousands of dollars from Trump's company by asking to be reimbursed for money he had not spent.\n\nMr Cohen acknowledged once telling a prosecutor he felt that Ms Daniels and her lawyer were extorting Trump.\n\nThough jurors witnessed numerous memorable moments, they will not be told during closing arguments about exchanges and rulings that occurred outside their presence - and there were many.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan, for instance, fined Trump 10,000 dollars (\u00a37,800) for violating a gag order barring incendiary out-of-court comments and threatened to jail him if it continued.\n\nThe New York prosecution is one of four criminal cases pending against Trump as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe three other state and federal cases centre on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election.\n\nBut it is unclear that any of them will reach trial before the November election.", "source": {"uri": "thenorthernecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Northern {"uri": "8150289002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:47:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:47:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:46:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/trump-hush-money-trial-closings-tcw457fz", "title": "Former Donald Trump lawyer Michael Cohen is 'greatest liar of all times,' defense attorney tells jury in hush money trial", "body": "Ex-President Donald Trump should be acquitted of all charges at his historic hush money trial because he did not falsify business records in an attempt to cover-up an alleged affair with an adult film actress to protect his chances at winning the 2016 presidential election, Trump's lead defense attorney said in his closing arguments to jurors Tuesday.\n\n\"President Trump is innocent,\" said Trump attorney Todd Blanche. \"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney did not meet the burden of proof.\"\n\nBlanche, in a summation that lasted nearly three hours, accused the prosecution's star witness Michael Cohen, a Lawrence native who was Trump's personal attorney, of lying while on the stand and cautioned the jury against convicting Trump based on the word of the now-disbarred attorney.\n\n\"Michael Cohen, he's the human embodiment of reasonable doubt. He lied to you,\" Blanche told the jury. \"He is biased and motivated to tell you a story that is not true. ... Michael Cohen is the GLOAT, greatest liar of all times.\"\n\nAnd in a highly charged statement that later earned the stern rebuke of the presiding judge, Blanche told the jury: \"You cannot, you cannot send someone to prison, you cannot convict someone based on the words of Michael Cohen.\"\n\nDefense attorneys are prohibited from arguing against convicting their clients based on a penalty they could receive if found guilty, as jurors in New York State have no role in sentencing criminal defendants. Judges are tasked with imposing sentences.\n\nAfter Blanche concluded his summation and the jury was dismissed for lunch, Manhattan prosecutor Joshua Steinglass accused Blanche of misconduct, calling his conduct \"a blatant and wholly unlawful attempt to curry sympathy for their client.\"\n\nSupreme Court Justice Juan Merchan agreed with the prosecution's request for the judge to make a curative instruction to the jury, telling the body to disregard Blanche's statement and pointing out that a prison sentence is not mandatory for the charges. Trump faces up to four years in prison if convicted, but could receive no jail time as a first-time offender in a white-collar case.\n\n\"I think saying that is outrageous,\" said Merchan. \"Someone who has been a prosecutor as long as you is simply outrageous. I can't believe that was inadvertent. It's simply not allowed.\"\n\nEarlier in his summation, Blanche emphasized the charges against Trump are based on documents -- not a sexual liaison or the inner workings of the tabloid industry -- which he argued shows that Trump, then the leader of the free world, had no involvement in the company's record-keeping.\n\n\"This case is about documents; it's a paper case,\" said Blanche. \"This is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago -- an account that President Trump has denied.\"\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of felony falsifying business records as part of what prosecutors alleged was a scheme to cover-up the payment of hush money to adult film actress Daniels, who testified -- in sometimes graphic detail -- that she had a sexual encounter with Trump at a celebrity golf tournament in 2016, during which Trump did not wear protection.\n\nProsecutors have said the cover-up was part of a pattern of ''catch and kill\" schemes, the heart of a \"criminal conspiracy\" between Trump, Cohen and supermarket tabloid publisher David Pecker, to buy negative stories about Trump and bury them as he sought the presidency against Hillary Clinton.\n\nThe charges of falsifying business records are misdemeanors, but were upgraded to felonies by prosecutors, who argued the crimes were committed in order to cover up another crime, which prosecutors said is conspiracy to promote an election by unlawful means.\n\nProsecutors have said the payment was illegally recorded in Trump Organization records as legal services as part of a retainer agreement, but neither the retainer nor the legal services existed.\n\nManhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, who has kept a relatively low profile during Trump's trial, was in court as Blanche delivered his closing. Three of Trump's children were also in attendance -- Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Trump's wife, Melania Trump -- who had only months before given birth to Trump's youngest son, Barron, now 18, at the time that Daniels alleged she bedded Trump -- was not.\n\nBlanche, in his summation, seized on the testimony of Trump employees to disprove that Trump directed the falsification of the records -- vouchers, invoices and checks -- with the intent to defraud, which jurors have to find in order to convict Trump.\n\n\"Is the personal ledger accurate? Were those bookings entered with the intent to defraud?\" Blanche asked the jury. \"Our conclusion is absolutely not.\"\n\nBlanche, who displayed some of the documents in question for the jury as he spoke, reminded the jury of testimony from one Trump employee who said that the vouchers were \"auto-generated from the information in the invoices.\" The word \"retainer\" was \"generated by the software,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"The records were not false and the intent was not to defraud,\" said Blanche.\n\nTrump's payments to Cohen -- $35,000 monthly -- were not repayment for the hush money, Blanche argued, but were simply what the documents stated -- legal services. Cohen was still acting as Trump's personal attorney at the time, Blanche argued, and it's preposterous to believe that Cohen would have worked for free, despite Cohen's testimony that he was making money from various entities at the time by trading on his connection to Trump, then the newly minted president.\n\n\"The prosecution will say that you know that President Trump saw all of these invoices because she testified that she stapled the invoices to the checks\" when she sent them to Washington, D.C.,\" Blanche told the jury. \"She told you about her general practice, but general practice is not proof beyond a reasonable doubt. She never spoke to President Trump. She just did what she always does. She got an invoice from a lawyer and entered it in as a legal expense.\"\n\nBlanche added: \"It was consistent with what she understood was happening at that time, which is that Michael Cohen was acting as President Trump's personal attorney. That is not in dispute.\"\n\nTrump was in the White House during this period and far removed from the running of his company, Blanche argued.\n\n\"President Trump was busy running the country,\" said Blanche.\"[White House aide] Ms. Westerhout testified that sometimes President Trump looked at the checks, sometimes he didn't. ... You can't convict President Trump because sometimes without anything specific at all to the charges in this case that he sometimes looked at invoices. That is a stretch. That is a stretch and that is reasonable doubt.\"\n\nCohen, himself, testified that he let the world know that he was working as Trump's lawyer.\n\n\"He put that signature block on every email he sent in 2017 -- Michael Cohen was President Trump's personal attorney. Period,\" said Blanche.\n\nBlanche asked the jury to think about what made more sense -- that Trump, as the prosecution alleges, reimbursed Cohen triple the $130,000 paid to Daniels, although Trump was described as penny-pinching by multiple witnesses? Or that the $420,000 that Trump paid Cohen, at a rate of $35,000 monthly, was Cohen's payment for working as Trump's personal attorney?\n\n\"There's a reason why in life, the simplest answer is the right one and the story that Michael Cohen told you on the witness stand is not true,\" said Blanche. \"The idea that President Trump would agree to pay Cohen $420,000 even though he only owed him $130,000 is absurd.\"\n\nBlanche added: \"You cannot convict President Trump beyond a reasonable doubt based on the testimony of Michael Cohen.\"\n\nBlanche pointed out that Trump repeatedly disclosed the payments to Cohen to various entities, including the Internal Revenue Service.\n\n\"How is there an intent to defraud if he discloses it to the IRS, he tweets about it and he puts it on his financial disclosure form?\" Blanche asked.\n\nBlanche also asked the jury to question why the prosecution declined to call some potential witnesses to the stand, including former Trump CFO Allen Weisselberg, ex-National Enquirer editor-in-chief Dylan Howard, and former Trump bodyguard and White House aide Keith Schiller and the two eldest Trump sons.\n\nThe notion that Trump, Cohen and Pecker cooked up a conspiracy to impact the presidential election during an Aug. 15, 2015 meeting at Trump Tower to \"catch and kill\" negative stories about Trump doesn't align with trial testimony, that included Pecker testifying that the National Enquirer's parent company -- American Media Inc. -- had long been in the practice of buying and burying stories for celebrities.\n\n\"This is the same thing that AMI had been doing for decades,\" said Blanche. \"They had been doing it for President Trump since the 90s. They purchase stories all the time. They did it with Mark Wahlberg, Tiger Woods. ... Many politicians work with the media to try to promote their image. It's how you try to win elections.\"\n\nEchoing what he emphasized in his opening statement -- that impacting an election is part of the democratic process -- Blanche said: This is a campaign. This is not a crime. Nothing criminal about it. It's done all the time.\"\n\nBlanche accused Cohen of lying about several parts of his testimony, and questioned a voice recording that Cohen made of Trump, in which they allegedly discussed a hush money payment to another woman, former Playboy model Karen McDougal, who said to have had an affair with Trump.\n\nBlanche cautioned jurors that they have \"no idea about the integrity of this file\" in which Trump is heard saying to pay \"cash.\"\n\n\"There's no way that you can believe that President Trump knew about this payment without believing the words of Michael Cohen,\" said Blanche. \"And you cannot, you cannot believe the words of Michael Cohen.\"\n\nBlanche, returning to a point he attempted to make during his cross-examination of Cohen, told the jury that Cohen perjured himself when he testified that he discussed the hush money payment agreement on a 90-second phone call with Trump on Oct. 24, 2016, which was patched through by Schiller, then Trump's bodyguard.\n\n\"It was a lie and he got caught red-handed,\" said Blanche. \"We all know that he called Mr. Schiller about a 14-year-old prank caller who had bothered him for a number of days.\"\n\nWith emphasis on each syllable, Blanche said: \"That is perjury.\"\n\nBlanche continued to attack Cohen, who testified that he was convicted previously of lying to Congress.\n\n\"He's repeatedly lied under oath,\" said Blanche. \"He's lied to his family. He lied to his banker, he lied, if you believe what he says on the stand, he lied to the feds, he lied to every reporter he spoke to before the election. He's like the MVP of liars. He's also a thief. He stole tens of thousands of dollars on the way out the door of the Trump Organization. He lied to you.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsday"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Cohen_(lawyer)", "type": {"uri": "8150333938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:27:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:27:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:23:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/trumps-acquittal-should-be-quick-lawyer-tells-jury-in-hush-money-trial-5766786", "title": "Trump's Acquittal Should Be \"Quick\": Lawyer Tells Jury In Hush Money Trial", "body": "Less than six months before American voters choose whether to return Trump to the White House, the stakes riding on the verdict are hard to overstate -- for the 77-year-old personally, but also for the country.\n\nIf convicted, Trump faces up to four years in prison on each of 34 counts (File)\n\nNew York:\n\nDefense lawyers in Donald Trump's hush money trial made their final pitch to the jury on Tuesday, calling for acquittal and insisting the first ever criminal prosecution of a former US president was based on \"lies.\"\n\nLess than six months before American voters choose whether to return Trump to the White House, the stakes riding on the verdict are hard to overstate -- for the 77-year-old personally, but also for the country.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying business records to reimburse his former lawyer Michael Cohen for a $130,000 payment to porn star Stormy Daniels, when her account of a 2006 sexual encounter could have doomed his 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nTrump's attorney Todd Blanche, delivering his closing argument, told the jury that the trial \"isn't a referendum on your views of president Trump\" or \"who you plan on voting for in 2024.\"\n\nProsecutors had failed to prove their case beyond a reasonable doubt, Blanche said, and the only outcome should be a \"very quick and easy not guilty verdict.\"\n\n\"President Trump is innocent,\" he said.\n\nBlanche spent much of his summation attacking Cohen, the prosecution's star witness, who has spent time in prison for tax evasion and other crimes, calling him the \"MVP of liars\" consumed by \"outright hatred for Trump.\"\n\n\"He's literally the greatest liar of all time,\" he said. \"He told you a number of things on that witness stand that were lies, pure and simple.\n\n\"You cannot convict president Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen.\"\n\nBlanche said Trump was \"busy running the country\" when the reimbursements were made to Cohen and he did not closely inspect all the invoices that came across his desk.\n\n\"There was no intent to defraud and beyond that there was no conspiracy to influence the 2016 election by president Trump,\" Blanche said. \"He did not commit any crimes.\"\n\nGraphic testimony\n\nTrump had a grave look on his face as his lawyer spoke, his head titled to the side studying the jurors. He raised his left hand in a fist as he left the courtroom for lunch but did not address the assembled media.\n\nSpeaking to reporters earlier before entering the Manhattan courtroom, Trump said \"this is a very dangerous day for America.\"\n\n\"We have a rigged court case that should have never been brought,\" he said as three of his five children -- Don Jr, Eric and Tiffany -- stood behind him.\n\nProsecutors will get the last word. They will lay out the case that Trump falsified records to keep the hush money payment secret amid fear that the episode could sink his already rocky outsider's bid to defeat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThe 12 jurors -- whose identities have been kept secret for their protection -- will start deliberations as early as Wednesday.\n\nPolls show Trump neck and neck against President Joe Biden in the White House race and the verdict will inject new tension into an already bitter contest.\n\nSpeaking on behalf of the Biden campaign outside court, actor Robert De Niro berated Trump as a \"clown\" and \"grubby real estate developer\" intent on destroying the country.\n\nTrump is the first former or sitting president under criminal indictment, with charges ranging from the relatively minor hush money case to accusations that he took top secret documents and tried to overthrow the 2020 election.\n\nThe New York case, which featured more than 20 witnesses over five weeks and days of gripping testimony by Daniels and Cohen, is the only one likely to come to trial by election day on November 5.\n\nIf convicted, Trump faces up to four years in prison on each of 34 counts, but legal experts say that as a first-time offender he is unlikely to get jail time.\n\nA conviction would not bar him from appearing on the ballot in November.\n\nUnanimity required\n\nTrump chose not to testify in his defense -- a move that would have exposed him to damaging cross-examination.\n\nInstead, he used his daily trips to court to stage televised tirades against \"corrupt\" Judge Juan Merchan, and to claim the trial is a Democratic ploy to keep him off the campaign trail.\n\nA number of Republican Trump loyalists, including several vying to be his vice president, have made the trek to the courtroom to sit behind him.\n\nTo return a guilty or not guilty verdict requires the jury to be unanimous. Just one holdout means a hung jury and a mistrial, although prosecutors could seek a new trial.\n\nIn addition to the New York case, Trump has been indicted in Washington and Georgia on charges of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nHe also faces charges in Florida of hoarding huge quantities of classified documents after leaving the White House.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": the stakes riding on the verdict are hard to overstate -- for the 77-year-old personally, but also for the country.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying business records to reimburse his lawyer, Michael dangerous day for America,\" Trump told reporters before entering the Manhattan courtroom as three of his five children -- Don Jr, Eric and Tiffany -- stood behind him. \"We have a rigged court case a first-time offender he is unlikely to get jail time.\n\nTrump would almost certainly appeal and a conviction would not in any case bar him from appearing on the ballot in November.\n\nAs expected, encounter in sometimes graphic detail and his once close personal attorney and fixer Cohen took the stand.\n\nTrump has used his daily trips to court to stage televised tirades against \"corrupt\" {"uri": "8149975799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:08:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:08:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:08:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/0440217527b3096c34264a0ffbece42f/latest-defense-lawyer-begins-delivering-closing-arguments", "title": "The Latest | Defense lawyer begins delivering closing arguments in Trump's hush money case", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Closing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him.\n\n\"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last.\n\nMerchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2\u00bd hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nDonald Trump stood and looked back for a moment after he arrived at the defense table for the start of closing arguments in his hush money trial. Sitting between two of his attorneys -- Todd Blanche and Emil Bove -- the former president appeared animated before the proceedings began, gesturing and chatting with his lawyers.\n\nSeated behind Trump are members of his family, including his sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. and his daughter Tiffany.\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\"\n\nThe former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said.\n\nHe was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.\n\nA small of supporters yelled \"We love Trump\" outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan Tuesday morning as Donald Trump's motorcade arrived. The supporters waved American flags and were wearing red \"Make America Great Again\" hats.\n\nInside, the prosecution team made its way into the courtroom, led by Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass, who is expected to make the prosecution's closing argument.\n\nAs has been his routine, Steinglass walked in carrying a file box full of papers.\n\nSeveral of Donald Trump's family members plan to be at court Tuesday for his hush money trial.\n\nThey include his sons, Don Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, daughter-in-law Lara Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos.\n\nOther family members have not yet joined him in court, including his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and his eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will have their final opportunity to address the jury in closing arguments.\n\nThe arguments don't count as evidence in the case charging Donald Trump with falsifying business records to cover up hush money payments during the 2016 presidential election. They'll instead function as hourslong recaps of the key points the lawyers want to leave jurors with before the panel disappears behind closed doors for deliberations.\n\nJurors over the course of a month have heard testimony about sex and bookkeeping, tabloid journalism and presidential politics. Their task ahead will be to decide whether prosecutors who have charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business records have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\nWith closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial expected to get underway Tuesday morning, jurors have a weighty task ahead of them -- deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of some, all or none of the 34 felony counts he's charged with.\n\nTo convict Trump of felony falsifying business records, prosecutors must convince jurors beyond a reasonable doubt that he not only falsified or caused business records to be entered falsely but also did so with intent to commit or conceal another crime. Any verdict must be unanimous.\n\nTo prevent a conviction, the defense simply needs to convince at least one juror that prosecutors haven't proved Trump's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard for criminal cases.\n\nNew York also has a misdemeanor falsifying business records charge, which requires proving only that a defendant made or caused the false entries, but it is not part of Trump's case and will not be considered by jurors.\n\nFor many Americans, Memorial Day weekend was a moment to remember the sacrifices of U.S. military personnel and to unplug from the bustle of daily life.\n\nFor others, it was a chance to snag a prime spot in line for entry into Donald Trump's hush money trial ahead of Tuesday's closing arguments. Last Friday afternoon saw several people camped out -- including professional line sitters with pup tents -- for a chance to see the tail end of the historic proceedings up close and personal.\n\nThough most of the seats inside the courtroom are reserved for lawyers, members of Trump's entourage, security personnel and journalists, a few are open to the general public.\n\nThe former president's Manhattan trial has drawn visitors from all over, including students from local schools and plenty of out-of-towners.\n\nClosing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are expected to begin on Tuesday, marking the beginning of the end of the historic proceedings that kicked off in April.\n\nProsecutors and defense lawyers will make their final pitch to jurors, hoping to sway them in one direction or another after more than four weeks of witness testimony.\n\nFollowing the conclusion of closing arguments, which are expected to last all day, Judge Juan M. Merchan will spend about an hour instructing the jury on the law governing the case, providing a roadmap for what it can and cannot take into account as it evaluates the Republican former president's guilt or innocence.\n\nJurors could begin deliberations as early as Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
