Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Here's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\n-- As Trump's hush money trial nears end, would-be spectators camp out for days to get inside\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n-- Trump hush money case: A timeline of key events\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nJURORS INSTRUCTED TO DISREGARD 'IMPROPER' DEFENSE COMMENT ABOUT SENDING TRUMP TO PRISON\n\nThe judge in Donald Trump's hush money trial told jurors after a lunch break that they must disregard an \"improper\" comment from defense lawyer Todd Blanche urging them not to send the former president to prison.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan gave the instructions after scolding Blanche before the break over the remark made near the end of the defense's summation.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPROSECUTION BEGINS ITS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass has begun delivering his closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial. He speaks from the same podium that Blanche used, looking directly at jurors from a position between the prosecution and defense tables.\n\n\"This case, at its core, is about a conspiracy and a cover-up,\" Steinglass said as he began.\n\nProsecutors have presented \"powerful evidence of the defendant's guilt,\" he said.\n\nAs he continued, Trump sat at the defense table with his body angled toward Steinglass, listening as Steinglass spoke.\n\nTRUMP'S KIDS HOLD NEWS CONFERENCE\n\nDonald Trump's children held a news conference outside the courthouse during a lunch break in his hush money trial, with Donald Trump Jr. echoing defense lawyer Todd Blanche and calling Michael Cohen \"the GOAT (greatest of all time) of liars.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHe said the Biden campaign holding a news conference at the trial showed the case was a \"political persecution\" and in using one of his father's frequent terms, called it a \"witch hunt.\"\n\n\"This is a sham. This is insane. It needs to stop,\" he said.\n\nHis brother Eric Trump decried \"political warfare\" and said his father is the \"toughest man I've ever seen\" and \"he endures this nonsense every single day.\"\n\n\"I want to say sorry to the jury that's in there. This has been the greatest colossal waste of time,\" he said.\n\nLara Trump, Eric Trump's wife and the Republican National Committee co-chair, said that Alvin Bragg, the top law enforcement officer in New York, was focusing on her father-in-law instead of crime in New York.\n\n\"If they can profit off it on the other side, so can we,\" she said, and plugged Trump's campaign website where donations can be accepted.\n\nSTEINGLASS TAKES ISSUE WITH 'RIDICULOUS COMMENT' FROM DEFENSE\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBefore an afternoon lunch break, the judge in Donald Trump's hush money trial scolded defense lawyer Todd Blanche for imploring jurors not to send Trump to prison on the words of Michael Cohen and said he would instruct the jury to disregard the comment.\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass had taken issue with what he cast as a \"ridiculous comment\" and asked the judge to intervene.\n\n\"I think that saying that was outrageous,\" Judge Juan M. Merchan scolded Blanche. \"Someone who's been a prosecutor as long as you have and a defense attorney as long as you have, you know that making a comment like that is highly inappropriate. It's simply not allowed. Period.\"\n\nIf Trump is convicted, sentencing will be up to the judge, not the jury.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment.\n\nDEFENSE IMPL\n\nORES JURY TO RETURN A 'NOT GUILTY' VERDICT\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche finished his summation Tuesday by telling jurors the hush money case \"isn't a referendum on your views of President Trump.\"\n\n\"This is not a referendum on the ballot box -- who you voted for in 2016 or 2020, who you plan on voting for in 2024. That is not what this is about,\" the attorney told jurors. \"The verdict you have to reach has to do with the evidence you heard in this courtroom,\" and nothing else, he reminds them.\n\nHe implored the jury to return a quick \"not guilty\" verdict.\n\nBLANCHE CALLS COHEN 'AN MVP OF LIARS'\n\nAs he neared the end of his summation on Tuesday, defense lawyer Todd Blanche reminded jurors of Michael Cohen's admitted fixation on Donald Trump -- and his desire to see him behind bars.\n\nBlanche played short clips of Cohen's podcast in which he commended District Attorney Alvin Bragg and said that the idea of seeing the former president booked on criminal charges \"fills me with delight.\"\n\nThe case against Trump is built around testimony from \"a witness that outright hates the defendant, wants him in jail, is actively making money off that hatred,\" Blanche said.\n\nWhile Cohen has testified that he lied to protect Trump, his family and others, Blanche asserted that the ex-lawyer \"is lying simply to protect Michael Cohen and nobody else. Period.\"\n\nBlanche's voice grew to a roar -- the loudest he had been all morning -- as he also declared that Cohen had lied about speaking to Trump by phone about the Stormy Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche called Cohen \"literally like an MVP of liars.\"\n\n\"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates,\" he said.\n\nDEFENSE SHARPENS CRITIQUE OF 'CATCH AND KILLS'\n\nTrump lawyer Todd Blanche on Tuesday questioned the prosecution's narrative that the Stormy Daniels payment in October 2016 was part of a conspiracy amongst Trump, Michael Cohen and the National Enquirer to suppress negative stories about the then-candidate through the practice known as \"catch and kill.\"\n\nCohen had known about Daniels' claim since it was published without her permission on a gossip website in 2011, Blanche said, adding that Daniels had authorized her manager to seek offers to sell the story in early 2016.\n\n\"Why did it not go anywhere for months and months and months if there was a catch-and-kill scheme?\" Blanche asked.\n\nCohen agreed to pay Daniels in the final weeks of the 2016 presidential campaign, after the leak of the \"Access Hollywood\" tape.\n\nBlanche reminded jurors of the two other stories prosecutors say were buried through \"catch and kill.\"\n\nThe National Enquirer paid $30,000 for a since-disproven rumor from a Trump Tower doorman and $150,000 to former Playboy model Karen McDougal for her claim of an affair with Trump, though publisher David Pecker testified the tabloid wasn't interested in pursuing her story at first because it couldn't be corroborated.\n\nPecker said he refused to pay Daniels because he didn't want to shell out any more money for Trump without getting repaid, leaving Cohen to make the deal himself.\n\nBlanche suggested the publisher didn't want anything to do with the story anyway.\n\n\"That's our conspiracy? That's the three catch and kills?\" Blanche said.\n\nDEFENSE TRIES TO DOWNPLAY 'ACCESS HOLLYWOOD' TAPE\n\nLawyer Todd Blanche tried on Tuesday to downplay the fallout from the \"Access Hollywood\" tape that sent Donald Trump's 2016 campaign into a tailspin, telling the jury: \"It was not a doomsday event.\"\n\nBlanche conceded in his summation that Trump was bothered by the story. \"Nobody wants their family to be subjected to that type of thing,\" he said. \"It doesn't matter if you're running for office, if you're running 'The Apprentice' ... Nobody wants their family exposed to that type of story.\"\n\nNonetheless, he argued characterizations of the tape as devastating were an exaggeration. He pointed to testimony from Trump's former assistant Madeleine Westerhout, whom he said cast the fallout as \"a couple of days of frustration and consternation.\"\n\nWesterhout, who was then working for the Republican National Committee in close coordination with the Trump campaign, had testified that the tape \"rattled the RNC leadership\" but that Trump wasn't thrown by it.\n\nReince Priebus, then-chair of the Republican National Committee, had told Trump after the tape was released that he had two choices: drop out of the race or lose by the largest margin in history, Trump's former chief strategist Steve Bannon has recounted.\n\nBLANCHE ARGUES 'PEOPLE ALREADY KNEW' ABOUT DANIELS' CLAIMS\n\nTurning to Stormy Daniels' story, defense lawyer Todd Blanche noted in his summation that her allegations of a 2006 sexual encounter with Donald Trump were aired on a gossip site in 2011 -- four years before Trump announced his presidential candidacy. Trump has denied having sex with Daniels.\n\n\"So how could this issue have influenced the election?\" Blanche argued. \"People already knew about the allegations.\"\n\nAt the behest of Daniels and Michael Cohen, the story was taken off the site.\n\nBlanche asserted that the real impetus behind Daniels' interest in making a deal in 2016 was that some people wanted to use the election as pressure to \"extort\" Trump.\n\nFollowing a brief morning break, Blanche singled out that Daniels issued two statements in 2018 denying that she'd ever had a sexual encounter with Trump. She testified earlier in the hush money trial that she signed off on them at her lawyer's urging.\n\nDEFENSE DENIES RECORDED CONVERSATION WAS ABOUT PAYOFF OF FORMER MODEL\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche spotlighted a key piece of prosecution evidence during his summation: the secret recording Michael Cohen says he made of himself briefing Donald Trump on a plan to buy the rights to former Playboy model Karen McDougal's story from the National Enquirer.\n\nBlanche said the September 2016 recording, which cuts off before the conversation finishes, is unreliable and was actually about a plan to buy a collection of material on Trump that the National Enquirer had been hoarding -- not McDougal. Cohen has said the audio cut off because the iPhone he was using to make the recording was receiving a phone call.\n\n\"There is no doubt that this recording discussed AMI and discussed Mr. Pecker,\" Blanche said, referring to the National Enquirer's parent company and then-publisher. \"There is a lot of doubt that it discussed Karen McDougal.\"\n\nAfter playing parts of the recording, Blanche urged jurors to trust their ears when deciphering a specific part -- whether Trump mentioned a dollar figure that he might have to spend, as Cohen and prosecutors contend, or whether he said something else.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump said, according to Cohen and prosecutors, as in $150,000.\n\n\"Listen to the recording. See if you hear one-fifty,\" Blanche told jurors.\n\nTRUMP CAMPAIGN HOLDS ITS OWN NEWS CONFERENCE\n\nDonald Trump's campaign staffers held their own news conference outside the courthouse Tuesday morning in the exact same spot where actor Robert De Niro and Jan. 6 officers had just spoken on behalf of Joe Biden's campaign.\n\nJason Miller, Trump's senior campaign advisor, called De Niro \"a washed-up actor,\" and said the news conference showed that the hush money trial was political.\n\n\"After months of saying politics had nothing to do with this trial, they showed up and made a campaign event out of a lower Manhattan trial day for President Trump,\" Miller said.\n\nKaroline Leavitt, the campaign press secretary, called the Biden campaign \"desperate and failing\" and \"pathetic\" and said their event outside the trial was \"a full-blown concession that this trial is a witch hunt that comes from the top.\"\n\nBLANCHE: 'THIS WASN'T A CATCH AND KILL'\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's hush money trial took issue on Tuesday with the notion that there was a conspiracy to suppress negative stories to help Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to American Media Inc.'s $30,000 payment to Dino Sajudin, a former Trump Tower doorman who falsely alleged the former president had fathered a child out of wedlock. It was one of three potentially damaging stories about Trump the tabloid did not run.\n\nBlanche then pointed to former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker's testimony that he saw the doorman story as a potential blockbuster and would gladly have published it if it had been true.\n\n\"This isn't a catch and kill. This is an opportunity,\" Blanche said. \"It was worth too much to catch and kill, full stop.\"\n\nHe also noted Pecker had testified that the tabloid only published about half the stories they purchased.\n\n\"That's meaningful. That matters,\" Blanche told the jury.\n\nHe later targeted prosecutors' portrayal of Karen McDougal's deal with AMI as part of the purported hush money conspiracy, emphasizing testimony from her lawyer and others that she didn't want her claim published.\n\nRather, Blanche said, the former Playboy model wanted to reenergize her career by getting into magazines, according to the testimony -- though McDougal herself didn't testify.\n\n\"This was not a catch-and-kill,\" Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE URGES JURORS TO DISREGARD 'CONSPIRACY' CONCERNS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche implored the jury in Donald Trump's criminal trial to reject the prosecution's contention that he engaged in a conspiracy to influence the 2016 election by involving himself in efforts to bury negative stories about him -- and to reject the allegation that, after the fact, he falsified records of Michael Cohen's payments to hide that conspiracy.\n\n\"The government wants you to believe that President Trump did these things with his records to conceal efforts to promote his successful candidacy in 2016, the year before,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"Even that, even if you find that is true, that is not enough ... it doesn't matter if there's a conspiracy to win an election. Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win.\"\n\nDEFENSE SAYS TRUMP WATCHES HIS FINANCE CAREFULLY\n\nAfter arguing earlier Tuesday that Donald Trump may not have been fully aware of all his invoices, defense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed to jurors that the former president was a stickler about watching his finances.\n\nMichael Cohen received $420,000 in all from Trump in 2017, a sum that the ex-lawyer and prosecutors in the former president's hush money case have said included the $130,000 reimbursement related to Stormy Daniels, a $50,000 repayment for an unrelated expense and a $60,000 bonus. On top of that, prosecutors have said, there was extra money to cover taxes that would be due on the $130,000 as income -- taxes that wouldn't apply if it had simply been paid as a business expense reimbursement.\n\n\"That is absurd,\" Blanche told jurors, pointing to \"all the other evidence you heard about how carefully President Trump watches his finances.\"\n\nACTOR ROBERT DE NIRO AND JAN. 6 FIRST RESPONDERS SPEAK NEAR TRUMP'S TRIAL\n\nBiden campaign deploys actor Robert De Niro, Jan. 6 first responders near Trump's trial\n\nJoe Biden's campaign sent actor Robert De Niro and two law enforcement officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 to an area in lower Manhattan not far from the criminal court where Donald Trump's hush money trial is happening.\n\nSpeaking while the former president was stuck in court, De Niro said Trump wants to \"destroy not only the city but the country and eventually he could destroy the world.\"\n\nAs he spoke, Trump protesters screamed anti-Biden chants.\n\nTRUMP WAS EXTREMELY BUSY WHEN SIGNING CHECKS, BLANCHE SAYS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed during his summation on Tuesday that Donald Trump was busy during the time when he signed the checks at the heart of the hush money case.\n\n\"It matters where President Trump was,\" Blanche said.\n\nHe noted Trump assistant Madeleine Westerhout had testified that the then-president would sometimes sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nBlanche argued it was unreasonable to suggest Trump was aware of the details of every invoice just because he knew of some. \"That is a stretch and that is reasonable doubt, ladies and gentlemen,\" he said.\n\nBLANCHE CRITICIZES PROSECUTIONS USE OF TRUMP'S BOOKS AND MORE\n\nAbout an hour into the defense's closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche took aim at the prosecution's use of excerpts from Trump's books to attempt to portray him as a detail-oriented micromanager who would be fully aware of any money his company was spending.\n\nThe books were from a decade ago, if not older, and were written with the help of ghostwriters, Blanche told the jury.\n\n\"You should be suspicious. That's a red flag,\" Blanche said in an effort to pre-empt the prosecution's closing.\n\nBlanche then started digging into the details of how payments to Michael Cohen were made, first through a trust set up to hold Trump's assets while he was in the White House, then through Trump's personal bank account with checks signed by the then-president.\n\n\"This was a very confusing time for the Trump Organization,\" Blanche said. There were a lot of adjustments being made as Trump's assets were put under the trust's control and it was the first time in decades that Trump wasn't in charge, he added.\n\nAt one point, early in the repayment process in 2017, the then-Trump Organization finance chief emailed a subordinate that it was OK to pay Cohen out of the trust per an agreement with Trump's sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr., who were running the Trump Organization's day-to-day operations at the time. Both were in court on Tuesday.\n\nBlanche questioned why, if prosecutors allege Trump was involved in a conspiracy to conceal the nature of the payments, the sons he put in charge of his company weren't called to the witness stand.\n\nCOHEN WAS TRUMP'S PERSONAL ATTORNEY, BLANCHE REITERATES\n\nA key part of prosecutors' claims in Donald Trump's hush money case is that his former lawyer Michael Cohen wasn't being paid for legal work in 2017, but rather was being reimbursed in a veiled way for the Stormy Daniels payment.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to emails and testimony Tuesday showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche noted that Cohen went on TV to discuss his role as Trump's personal lawyer and put the title in the signature block of every email he sent.\n\n\"This was not a secret. Michael Cohen was President Trump's personal attorney. Period,\" he said.\n\nBIDEN AND TRUMP CAMPAIGNS HOLD DUELING NEWS CONFERENCES OUTSIDE COURTHOUSE\n\nJoe Biden's campaign announced on Tuesday that it would hold an event with \"special guests\" as closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are underway.\n\nTrump spokesman Jason Miller said the former president's allies will respond with their own event immediately following Biden's.\n\nHe posted on the social platform X that Biden's allies \"aren't in PA, MI, WI, NV, AZ or GA -- they're outside the Biden Trial against President Trump,\" adding: \"It's always been about politics.\"\n\nPOWERPOINT CLOSING\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.\n\nDEFENSE BEGINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche began his closing argument Tuesday morning by telling jurors that Donald Trump \"is innocent\" of the charges against him.\n\n\"He did not commit any crimes and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof. Period,\" Blanche said before adding that evidence in the case \"should leave you wanting.\"\n\n\"This case is about documents. It's a paper case. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, an encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied ever occurred,\" Blanche said. \"Nor is it about the confidential settlement and non-disclosure agreement that Daniels entered into eight years ago.\"\n\nMERCHAN EXPLAINS CLOSING ARGUMENTS PROCESS\n\nJurors in Donald Trump's criminal trial were attentive Tuesday morning as Judge Juan M. Merchan explained the closing arguments process -- that by law the defense must go first and prosecutors must go last.\n\nMerchan says he'll leave it up to the jury if they want to work past 4:30 p.m., the normal end of the court day, to accommodate both summations in their entirety, rather than spilling into Wednesday.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche said he expects to speak for about 2 1/2 hours during the defense's part of closing arguments while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass said he may go as long as 4 1/2 hours.\n\nTRUMP: IT'S 'A DARK DAY IN AMERICA'\n\nDonald Trump spoke to reporters before heading into the courtroom on Tuesday morning, calling it \"a dark day in America\" and \"a very sad day.\"\n\nThe former president carried a sheet of paper and read quotes off of it from political and legal commentators who have attacked the hush money case, a feature Trump has made a regular part of his trial routine. He called Judge Juan M. Merchan \"corrupt\" and \"conflicted\" but said he couldn't speak about it because of the gag order.\n\n\"We'll see how it goes. This is a very dangerous day for America. It's a very sad day,\" Trump said.\n\nHe was accompanied by three of his children, Don Jr., Eric and Tiffany, along with one of his de facto campaign managers Susie Wiles.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8150442501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:03:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:03:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:01:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://weeklyblitz.net/2024/05/29/high-stakes-as-trump-trial-nears-conclusion/", "title": "High stakes as Trump trial nears conclusion - BLiTZ", "body": "In a case that has captured the attention of the nation and the world, prosecutors in the trial of Donald Trump are set to make their final pitch to the jury on Tuesday, May 28, 2024. This historic trial marks the first time a former US president faces the possibility of a criminal conviction. With less than six months before American voters decide whether to return Trump to the White House, the stakes of the verdict extend far beyond Trump's personal fate, impacting the country as a whole.\n\nTrump stands accused of falsifying business records to silence adult film star Stormy Daniels about a 2006 sexual encounter, a scandal that had the potential to derail his 2016 presidential campaign. If convicted, Trump faces up to four years in prison for each of the 34 counts against him. However, legal experts suggest that as a first-time offender, he is unlikely to serve jail time.\n\nCrucially, a conviction would not prevent Trump from running for president in the upcoming election. He remains the Republican frontrunner and is expected to challenge Democratic incumbent Joe Biden in November.\n\nAfter nearly five weeks of intense courtroom drama, featuring the testimony of over 20 witnesses and several high-profile moments, the trial has reached its closing arguments. This represents the final opportunity for both the prosecution and the defense to sway the anonymous 12-member jury. As anticipated, Trump chose not to testify in his defense, avoiding potential legal jeopardy and the rigors of cross-examination. Instead, he endured listening to Daniels recount their alleged encounter in sometimes graphic detail.\n\nThroughout the trial, Trump has been vocal outside the courtroom, often railing against Judge Juan Merchan, whom he labeled as \"corrupt\" and a \"tyrant.\" He has characterized the trial as an attempt at \"election interference\" orchestrated by Democrats to hinder his campaign efforts.\n\nThe political implications of the case have been evident, particularly in the final days, when prominent Republicans, including several potential vice-presidential candidates, showed their support by standing behind Trump as he addressed the press.\n\nJudge Merchan has indicated that closing arguments will occupy the entirety of Tuesday. Following these arguments, he will deliver his final instructions to the jury, who are expected to commence deliberations on Wednesday. A unanimous decision is required to return a guilty or not guilty verdict. A single dissenting juror would result in a hung jury and a mistrial.\n\nKey testimony for the prosecution came from Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal lawyer and \"fixer.\" Cohen testified that he facilitated the $130,000 hush money payment to ensure Daniels' story would not jeopardize Trump's presidential bid. The defense sought to undermine Cohen's credibility, highlighting his past admissions of lying to Congress and his imprisonment for tax fraud.\n\nApart from this New York case, Trump faces legal battles on multiple fronts. He has been indicted in Washington, D.C., and Georgia on charges of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election. Additionally, he faces charges in Florida for allegedly mishandling classified documents post-presidency. None of these trials are expected to commence before the November election, leaving the New York case as the most immediate legal challenge Trump faces.\n\nThe outcome of this trial carries significant implications not only for Trump but for the broader political landscape in the United States. A conviction could energize Trump's base, who may view him as a victim of a politically motivated prosecution. Conversely, it could also galvanize his opponents, underscoring their portrayal of Trump as unfit for office.\n\nThe trial has unfolded against a backdrop of a deeply divided nation, where political allegiances often color perceptions of legal proceedings. Trump's supporters have largely dismissed the charges as a partisan witch hunt, while his detractors see the trial as a necessary step in holding him accountable for his actions.\n\nThe case hinges on whether Trump falsified business records to conceal the hush money payment to Daniels. Prosecutors argue that this payment was intended to prevent damage to Trump's 2016 campaign. Daniels' testimony detailed the alleged encounter and the subsequent efforts to buy her silence, providing a narrative of deception and cover-up.\n\nMichael Cohen's testimony was pivotal, as he described his role in orchestrating the payment and the pressure he felt to protect Trump's chances of winning the presidency. The defense countered by attacking Cohen's credibility, painting him as a disgraced lawyer with a motive to lie.\n\nTrump's legal team has focused on discrediting the key witnesses, particularly Cohen, and arguing that the payments were legal and not intended to influence the election. They have portrayed the prosecution's case as weak and politically driven, emphasizing the lack of direct evidence linking Trump to any criminal intent.\n\nBy choosing not to testify, Trump avoided the risks associated with cross-examination but also missed an opportunity to directly address the allegations against him. His defense has instead relied on casting doubt on the prosecution's motives and the credibility of their witnesses.\n\nAs the trial draws to a close, the responsibility now rests with the jury. They must weigh the evidence presented over the past five weeks and reach a unanimous decision. The complexity of the case, combined with its high-profile nature, places immense pressure on the jurors.\n\nRegardless of the verdict, the trial represents a significant moment in American history, underscoring the legal challenges that can arise when a former president is accused of criminal conduct. It also highlights the enduring impact of Trump's presidency and his continued influence on the nation's political discourse.\n\nAs the jury prepares to deliberate, the nation watches with bated breath. The trial of Donald Trump is more than just a legal proceeding; it is a reflection of the deep political and social divisions in the United States. The outcome will likely resonate far beyond the courtroom, influencing the upcoming presidential election and shaping the legacy of one of the most controversial figures in American political history. Whether Trump is found guilty or not, this trial has already made its mark as a historic and pivotal event in the ongoing saga of Donald Trump.", "source": {"uri": "weeklyblitz.net", "dataType": It's a paper affair. This is not a meeting with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago, one that President Trump has repeatedly and adamantly denied took place. \"\n\nHe argued that the allegations - that business records were falsified to conceal repayment of secret payments to Daniels - were in fact \"accurate and there was absolutely no intent to defraud.\"\n\nThe jurors are in for a long day. The defense says it will need about 2.5 hours for its conclusions; the prosecution says it will take 4.5 hours. This will take all day and could mean jurors will be asked to stay past the 4:30 p.m. finish time.\n\nThe courtroom is also packed with notable figures, including Trump's daughter Tiffany, sons Eric and Don Jr., and Eric's wife Lara, co-chair of the Republican National Committee, according to Politico. Also present: District Attorney Alvin Bragg, who brought the case.\n\nThe Biden campaign, meanwhile, is planning a news conference outside the courthouse, marking perhaps the first time the president's re-election efforts have weighed in on the trial. Two of Trump's spokespeople -- Jason Miller and Steven Cheung -- were present outside to listen to the remarks and perhaps rebut a bit for the cameras.\n\nPREVIOUSLY: Donald Trump's secret trial draws to a close, as lawyers present closing arguments today before the case goes to the jury.\n\nWith huge stakes for the former and possibly future president, jurors will decide whether machinations around a 2016 payment by Michael Cohen, then Trump's lawyer, to porn star Stormy Daniels add up to conspiracy criminal in violation of campaign finance and tax laws. .\n\nThe Manhattan district attorney accuses Trump of approving an illegal scheme in the final round of the 2016 presidential campaign to bury Daniels' claim that he had a long-ago extramarital sexual relationship. Cohen paid Daniels $130,000 for his silence in October, using a home equity loan that he funneled to Daniels' attorney through a shell company created expressly for the transaction. Prosecutors say the crime was that Trump authorized a false paper trail to disguise his reimbursement to Cohen as routine legal work.\n\nThe latest chapter of the trial follows nearly five weeks of testimony ranging from the mundane cataloging of financial documents to the uncomfortable details of an alleged 2006 sexual relationship between Trump and Daniels that triggered the events that led to this affair.\n\nJurors saw Daniels clash with a Trump defense attorney, Susan Necheles, over the adult entertainer's veracity, his career choices and motivations for claiming Trump cheated on his wife, Melania Trump . They watched as defense attorney Todd Blanche called Cohen a liar for his testimony about contacting Trump to signal that a deal with Daniels was imminent.\n\nThey also saw Trump's former White House communications director, Hope Hicks, cry on the stand and -- before being removed from the courtroom by Judge Juan Merchan -- saw a Trump ally, Robert Costello, grunting in a \"ridiculous\" manner when the judge was subjected to a complaint. prosecutor's objection to part of his testimony.\n\nThey heard from nearly two dozen witnesses in total, including two called as part of the defense team's relatively brief rebuttal. They have not heard from Trump, who exercised his right as a criminal defendant not to appear in court.\n\nMeanwhile, jurors saw reams of texts, emails and phone histories collected by both sides. They will have to decide whether the documents and testimony prove an illegal conspiracy to influence the 2016 presidential election using fraudulent accounting, or show nothing more than messy behind-the-scenes maneuvering in a national political campaign.\n\nJurors were given a week off to return to normal lives while following Merchan's instructions to avoid trial coverage and commentary. The judicial blackout imposed on jurors to avoid exposure to the unprecedented case includes social media, where Trump was busy during the break proclaiming his innocence and portraying the judge and prosecutors as his executioners. Among Trump's complaints on his Truth Social platform, Merchan gave jurors seven days off and did not sequester them. He also complained that the prosecution had the final say in the case, even though that is standard procedure in a trial.\n\nTrump denies having sex with Daniels. She was spotted departing Trump Tower in advance or her father's move to the court Tuesday morning for the first time in nearly a week. Then, she stood behind Trump as he once again railed against the prosecution.\n\nShe was seated inside the courtroom on the aisle next to Eric's wife Lara Trump, who is a co-chair of the Republican National Committee. Her husband Michael Boulos was also there for closing arguments in the Stormy Daniels trial.\n\nTiffany, a Georgetown Law graduate, is getting the chance to see Trump lawyer Todd Blanche weave together closing arguments that were set to last about two and a half hours. It is a critical aspect of trial law, referencing evidence and testimony jurors may have heard weeks ago to try to steer them toward a verdict of not guilty.\n\nJust days ago, Blanche had asked star witness Michael Cohen during cross-examination about the apparent 'extortion' attempt involving Tiffany. It was part of an effort to undercut Cohen's own testimony that he was speaking to Trump about the Stormy Daniels matter during a critical period, rather than other matters that might have risen to the top of his to-do list.\n\n'You agree with me, right, that you had a lot going on both in your personal life and with President Trump in those first two weeks of October?' Blanche asked the witness during a long cross-examination where he poked holes in his story. 'You recall on October 25th, you recall her communicating with you concerns about somebody trying to blackmail her?' Blanche asked. 'Yes sir,' Cohen responded.\n\nThat was the day after Cohen testified that he spoke to Trump to tell him the Stormy Daniels matter was resolved and said Trump authorized the plan to pay her off. Cohen says he reached Trump on the phone by ringing Trump security chief Keith Schiller's phone.\n\nBlanche later established through text messages that Cohen was also dealing with a prank caller at the time, and accused him of lying about ever discussing the Stormy Daniels pay off during the call. Tiffany has kept a lower profile than her older siblings, whose mother is the late Ivana Trump.\n\nShe appeared with him at the 2016 Republican convention, but didn't join him at the White House like Ivanka did, and was at school during the period when Eric and Don Jr. were helming the Trump Organization along with exec Allen Weisselberg. Her appearance comes after DailyMail.com reported that Tiffany's husband Michael Boulos and his billionaire Lebanese father are helping court Arab-Americans for Trump.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "8150350844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:39:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:39:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:38:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://townhall.com/tipsheet/mattvespa/2024/05/28/will-trump-be-convicted-n2639571", "title": "Will Trump Be Convicted?", "body": "It's closing argument day. The hush money trial involving Donald Trump and his alleged payments to adult entertainment star Stormy Daniels is coming to an end. The trial focused on falsifying business records to cover said payments, which are charges seldom brought to trial because it's not worth the hassle. This case isn't some Enron-like scandal.\n\nIf you want to play this game, this campaign finance violation comes with a fine, not jail time. Most cases of this nature come with a slap on the wrist. When jail time was recommended in past cases, most were no more than a month. We're dealing with a misdemeanor charge that Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg opted to elevate to felony status for political reasons.\n\nSo, what's going to happen? The jury pool is biased against Trump, which we all saw during the voir dire stage of this circus. While exoneration should be the verdict since I don't know anyone who would have changed their vote if Trump's reported tryst was made public, it's either conviction or a hung jury.\n\nPolitico outlined the possible outcomes, though they did highlight at length, albeit buried in the story, how Michael Cohen was an atrocious witness for the prosecution since he's a serial liar who got exposed for being such again during cross-examination. Yet, before that, they had to go through the scenario where the former president is convicted:\n\nBroadly speaking, the D.A.'s office has provided two logical paths for jurors to use to convict Trump -- one that goes through Cohen and one that goes around him.\n\nThe path through Cohen relies on his testimony about purported conversations that he had with Trump about the relevant events in 2016 and 2017.\n\nIf you believe Cohen, his testimony broadly established Trump's involvement in and knowledge of the underlying effort to purchase Daniels' story in order to ensure that it did not hurt Trump's 2016 election chances; prosecutors have characterized that scheme as a conspiracy to influence the election using an illegal campaign contribution. Cohen's testimony also sought to establish the process for Trump reimbursing Cohen for the payment to Daniels using intentionally falsified business records.\n\nThe second path to a conviction relies on circumstantial evidence, inference and common sense -- all of which, as a legal matter, are perfectly appropriate grounds upon which jurors can render a verdict.\n\nThere is plenty of reason, even apart from the direct evidence offered by Cohen of Trump's participation in approving the deal with Daniels and signing off on the false records regarding the reimbursement, to believe that Trump was in on everything and fully aware of the legal risks and implications of what he had done.\n\nAfter all, Trump was the only full-time participant in all of the key events. He was the person who had sex with Daniels. He was the candidate running for president whose political interests were at risk if Daniels' account became public. He was a principal (represented by Cohen) in the contract negotiations to acquire Daniels' story. He was the person who ultimately gave the money for Daniels to stay quiet. And he was the head of the business whose records were falsified in the course of repaying Cohen.\n\nThese two paths -- one relying largely on Cohen's testimony, and one relying largely on circumstantial evidence of Trump's intent to conceal the commission of a crime when he reimbursed Cohen -- aren't mutually exclusive. For prosecutors to prevail, the jurors don't have to agree on their reasoning, either, as long as they agree to convict.\n\nA conviction, however, is not a foregone conclusion.\n\nThe most obvious path to doing so is -- and has always been -- to focus on Cohen's credibility issues. After all, according to a poll conducted by Ipsos and POLITICO Magazine in the run-up to the trial, roughly half of the country already believes that Cohen is dishonest.\n\nThese facts are arguably consistent with a legally innocuous scenario: Trump relied on his lawyer and CFO to ensure that Daniels was paid, but he was not aware of the underlying legal implications, and at the point of repaying Cohen, he did not intend to conceal the commission of \"another crime.\" Justice Juan Merchan precluded Trump's lawyers from offering a very shaky \"advice of counsel\" defense -- which basically would have allowed Trump to claim that he was simply following Cohen's advice -- but the facts about Cohen and Weisselberg's involvement hang over the case regardless, and the practical implications may prove unavoidable for one or more of the jurors.\n\nOn paper at least, Trump lawyer Todd Blanche's lengthy cross-examination of Cohen also drew out a series of damaging concessions that are likely to feature prominently in the closing argument.\n\nFirst, Blanche appears to have established that Cohen is a serial, unrepentant liar who has often lied in legal proceedings to advance his own self-interest. In addition to lying to Congress (which was plausibly done for Trump), Cohen also lied to the Justice Department, to his bank and also to the IRS -- all of which he did to help himself personally and financially. He also claims that he lied to the federal judge who took his guilty plea on tax fraud charges.\n\nSecond, Blanche appears to have established that Cohen has two classic motives to lie about Trump: vengeance and greed. Cohen acknowledged that he wants to see Trump go to prison the same way he did. He also conceded that he has made millions of dollars working in the media after turning against Trump and improbably becoming something of a hero to the sort of anti-Trump news consumers who get all of their information from cable and social media.\n\nThird, and most damagingly, Blanche credibly identified several possible lies that Cohen told on the stand when he was being questioned on direct examination by prosecutors.\n\nThere is more text in the piece about there being a hung jury verdict than a conviction in the piece, though it's buried. And yes, most it is because Cohen is not a credible witness, whose testimony is scarce on corroborating facts:\n\n\"A related weakness in the case also became clear on cross-examination: Cohen was never fully corroborated by other evidence...\n\nTake, for instance, Cohen's call with Schiller [Trump's bodyguard] (and maybe Trump) in late October 2016. The fact of the call is corroborated by phone records, but what happened on the call -- whether it was about Daniels, the 14-year-old kid prank-calling Cohen or both -- is not, and of course, it is the content of the call that matters most.\n\nThe piece lists two other instances of Cohen's testimony that cannot be verified, one of which centered on potential criminal intent on behalf of Trump regarding Cohen's reimbursement in this purported scheme. Still, the other witness, Allen Weisselberg, was never called to testify. Also, I hope it wasn't lost on anyone that Cohen seems to admit stealing money from the Trump Organization, an act that is more felonious than anything Trump is dealing with right now:\n\n\"These are all credible flaws and gaps in the prosecutors' case against Trump. Whether Trump's legal team can mine them effectively enough to persuade at least one juror to side with them, of course, remains to be seen,\" Politico added.\n\nThis trial appears to be the best shot the Left has at a conviction. With Special Counsel Jack Smith's trials against the former president postponed indefinitely and the Georgia RICO case stalled due to alleged ethics violations committed on behalf of the prosecution, this four-pronged legal offensive against Trump has fizzled for now.", "source": {"uri": "townhall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Townhall"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matt_vespa@townhall.com", {"uri": "8150361970", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:51:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:51:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:48:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/the-latest-prosecution-begins-its-closing-arguments-in-trumps-hush-money-case/article_78b9b6f8-c9ab-51b4-87ae-cf2b70c47db1.html", "title": "The Latest | Prosecution begins its closing arguments in Trump's hush money case", "body": "Robert De Niro, center, argues with a Donald Trump supporter after speaking to reporters in support of President Joe Biden across the street from Trump's criminal trial in New York, Tuesday, May 28, 2024.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Closing arguments in Donald Trump 's historic hush money trial began Tuesday morning in a Manhattan courtroom, giving prosecutors and defense attorneys one final opportunity to convince the jury of their respective cases before deliberations begin.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche spoke for about 2 1/2 hours in the morning while prosecutor Joshua Steinglass was expected to go as long as 4\u00bd hours.\n\nJurors will undertake the unprecedented task of deciding whether to convict the former U.S. president of felony criminal charges stemming from hush money payments tied to an alleged scheme to buy and bury stories that might wreck Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nAt the heart of the charges are reimbursements paid to Michael Cohen for a $130,000 hush money payment that was given to porn actor Stormy Daniels in exchange for not going public with her claim about a 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.\n\nProsecutors say the payments to Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer, were falsely logged as \"legal expenses\" to hide the true nature of the transactions.\n\nTrump has denied all wrongdoing.\n\nHe pleaded not guilty to 34 counts of falsifying business records, charges which are punishable by up to four years in prison.\n\nClosing arguments are expected to last all day Tuesday, with jury deliberations beginning as soon as Wednesday.\n\nThe case is the first of Trump's four indictments to go to trial as he seeks to reclaim the White House from Democrat Joe Biden.\n\nThe other cases center on charges of illegally hoarding classified documents at his estate in Palm Beach, Florida, and conspiring to overturn the 2020 presidential election. It's unclear whether any of them will reach trial before the November election.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Here's what every key witness said at Donald Trump's hush money trial\n\n-- As Trump's hush money trial nears end, would-be spectators camp out for days to get inside\n\n-- Closing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? Major week looms\n\n-- Trump hush money case: A timeline of key events\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: A guide to unique terms used at Trump's trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nPROSECUTION TRIES TO COUNTER DEFENSE'S EFFORTS TO DISCREDIT COHEN\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass on Tuesday afternoon tried in his summation to counter the defense's efforts to discredit Michael Cohen's testimony.\n\nHe said that the jury should take Cohen's past dishonesty into account.\n\n\"How could you not?\" he asked.\n\nBut he says that Cohen's anger is understandable given that, \"To date, he's the only one that's paid the price for his role in this conspiracy.\"\n\nCohen, Steinglass argued, did Trump's bidding for years, was his right-hand man, and when things went bad, was cut loose and thrown under the bus.\n\n\"Anyone in Cohen's shoes would want the defendant to be held accountable,\" he argued.\n\nALLEGATIONS OF EXTORTION ARE 'NOT A DEFENSE TO ELECTION FRAUD,' PROSECUTOR SAYS\n\nAt the outset of its summation in Donald Trump's hush money trial, the prosecution sought to rebut the defense's claim that porn actor Stormy Daniels was trying to \"extort\" the then-presidential candidate.\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass noted that Daniels' representatives initially sought to sell the story of a sexual encounter between the porn actor and Trump to media outlets -- not to Trump. Steinglass also cited Daniels' testimony that she came to believe that going public was the best way to protect herself and her family from pressure to stay silent.\n\nRegardless, allegations of extortion are \"not a defense to election fraud,\" the prosecutor said.\n\n\"You don't get to commit election fraud or falsify business records because you believe you've been victimized,\" he told jurors.\n\nJURORS INSTRUCTED TO DISREGARD 'IMPROPER' DEFENSE COMMENT ABOUT SENDING TRUMP TO PRISON\n\nThe judge in Donald Trump's hush money trial told jurors after a lunch break that they must disregard an \"improper\" comment from defense lawyer Todd Blanche urging them not to send the former president to prison.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan gave the instructions after scolding Blanche before the break over the remark made near the end of the defense's summation.\n\nPROSECUTION BEGINS ITS CLOSING ARGUMENTS\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass has begun delivering his closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial. He speaks from the same podium that Blanche used, looking directly at jurors from a position between the prosecution and defense tables.\n\n\"This case, at its core, is about a conspiracy and a cover-up,\" Steinglass said as he began.\n\nProsecutors have presented \"powerful evidence of the defendant's guilt,\" he said.\n\nAs he continued, Trump sat at the defense table with his body angled toward Steinglass, listening as Steinglass spoke.\n\nTRUMP'S KIDS HOLD NEWS CONFERENCE\n\nDonald Trump's children held a news conference outside the courthouse during a lunch break in his hush money trial, with Donald Trump Jr. echoing defense lawyer Todd Blanche and calling Michael Cohen \"the GOAT (greatest of all time) of liars.\"\n\nHe said the Biden campaign holding a news conference at the trial showed the case was a \"political persecution\" and in using one of his father's frequent terms, called it a \"witch hunt.\"\n\n\"This is a sham. This is insane. It needs to stop,\" he said.\n\nHis brother Eric Trump decried \"political warfare\" and said his father is the \"toughest man I've ever seen\" and \"he endures this nonsense every single day.\"\n\n\"I want to say sorry to the jury that's in there. This has been the greatest colossal waste of time,\" he said.\n\nLara Trump, Eric Trump's wife and the Republican National Committee co-chair, said that Alvin Bragg, the top law enforcement officer in New York, was focusing on her father-in-law instead of crime in New York.\n\n\"If they can profit off it on the other side, so can we,\" she said, and plugged Trump's campaign website where donations can be accepted.\n\nSTEINGLASS FLAGS 'RIDICULOUS COMMENT' FROM DEFENSE\n\nBefore an afternoon lunch break, the judge in Donald Trump's hush money trial scolded defense lawyer Todd Blanche for imploring jurors not to send Trump to prison on the words of Michael Cohen and said he would instruct the jury to disregard the comment.\n\nProsecutor Joshua Steinglass had taken issue with what he cast as a \"ridiculous comment\" and asked the judge to intervene.\n\n\"I think that saying that was outrageous,\" Judge Juan M. Merchan scolded Blanche. \"Someone who's been a prosecutor as long as you have and a defense attorney as long as you have, you know that making a comment like that is highly inappropriate. It's simply not allowed. Period.\"\n\nIf Trump is convicted, sentencing will be up to the judge, not the jury.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, charges punishable by up to four years in prison. It's unclear whether prosecutors would seek imprisonment in the event of a conviction, or if the judge would impose that punishment.\n\nDEFENSE IMPLORES JURY TO RETURN A 'NOT GUILTY' VERDICT\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche finished his summation Tuesday by telling jurors the hush money case \"isn't a referendum on your views of President Trump.\"\n\n\"This is not a referendum on the ballot box -- who you voted for in 2016 or 2020, who you plan on voting for in 2024. That is not what this is about,\" the attorney told jurors. \"The verdict you have to reach has to do with the evidence you heard in this courtroom,\" and nothing else, he reminds them.\n\nHe implored the jury to return a quick \"not guilty\" verdict.\n\nBLANCHE CALLS COHEN 'AN MVP OF LIARS'\n\nAs he neared the end of his summation on Tuesday, defense lawyer Todd Blanche reminded jurors of Michael Cohen's admitted fixation on Donald Trump -- and his desire to see him behind bars.\n\nBlanche played short clips of Cohen's podcast in which he commended District Attorney Alvin Bragg and said that the idea of seeing the former president booked on criminal charges \"fills me with delight.\"\n\nThe case against Trump is built around testimony from \"a witness that outright hates the defendant, wants him in jail, is actively making money off that hatred,\" Blanche said.\n\nWhile Cohen has testified that he lied to protect Trump, his family and others, Blanche asserted that the ex-lawyer \"is lying simply to protect Michael Cohen and nobody else. Period.\"\n\nBlanche's voice grew to a roar -- the loudest he had been all morning -- as he also declared that Cohen had lied about speaking to Trump by phone about the Stormy Daniels arrangement on Oct. 24, 2016.\n\n\"It was a lie,\" Blanche said. \"That was a lie and he got caught red-handed.\"\n\nBlanche called Cohen \"literally like an MVP of liars.\"\n\n\"He lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family and business associates,\" he said.\n\nDEFENSE TRIES TO DOWNPLAY 'ACCESS HOLLYWOOD' TAPE\n\nLawyer Todd Blanche tried on Tuesday to downplay the fallout from the \"Access Hollywood\" tape that sent Donald Trump's 2016 campaign into a tailspin, telling the jury: \"It was not a doomsday event.\"\n\nBlanche conceded in his summation that Trump was bothered by the story. \"Nobody wants their family to be subjected to that type of thing,\" he said. \"It doesn't matter if you're running for office, if you're running 'The Apprentice' ... Nobody wants their family exposed to that type of story.\"\n\nNonetheless, he argued characterizations of the tape as devastating were an exaggeration. He pointed to testimony from Trump's former assistant Madeleine Westerhout, whom he said cast the fallout as \"a couple of days of frustration and consternation.\"\n\nWesterhout, who was then working for the Republican National Committee in close coordination with the Trump campaign, had testified that the tape \"rattled the RNC leadership\" but that Trump wasn't thrown by it.\n\nReince Priebus, then-chair of the Republican National Committee, had told Trump after the tape was released that he had two choices: drop out of the race or lose by the largest margin in history, Trump's former chief strategist Steve Bannon has recounted.\n\nBLANCHE ARGUES 'PEOPLE ALREADY KNEW' ABOUT DANIELS' CLAIMS\n\nTurning to Stormy Daniels' story, defense lawyer Todd Blanche noted in his summation that her allegations of a 2006 sexual encounter with Donald Trump were aired on a gossip site in 2011 -- four years before Trump announced his presidential candidacy. Trump has denied having sex with Daniels.\n\n\"So how could this issue have influenced the election?\" Blanche argued. \"People already knew about the allegations.\"\n\nAt the behest of Daniels and Michael Cohen, the story was taken off the site.\n\nBlanche asserted that the real impetus behind Daniels' interest in making a deal in 2016 was that some people wanted to use the election as pressure to \"extort\" Trump.\n\nFollowing a brief morning break, Blanche singled out that Daniels issued two statements in 2018 denying that she'd ever had a sexual encounter with Trump. She testified earlier in the hush money trial that she signed off on them at her lawyer's urging.\n\nDEFENSE DENIES RECORDED CONVERSATION WAS ABOUT PAYOFF OF FORMER MODEL\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche spotlighted a key piece of prosecution evidence during his summation: the secret recording Michael Cohen says he made of himself briefing Donald Trump on a plan to buy the rights to former Playboy model Karen McDougal's story from the National Enquirer.\n\nBlanche said the September 2016 recording, which cuts off before the conversation finishes, is unreliable and was actually about a plan to buy a collection of material on Trump that the National Enquirer had been hoarding -- not McDougal. Cohen has said the audio cut off because the iPhone he was using to make the recording was receiving a phone call.\n\n\"There is no doubt that this recording discussed AMI and discussed Mr. Pecker,\" Blanche said, referring to the National Enquirer's parent company and then-publisher. \"There is a lot of doubt that it discussed Karen McDougal.\"\n\nAfter playing parts of the recording, Blanche urged jurors to trust their ears when deciphering a specific part -- whether Trump mentioned a dollar figure that he might have to spend, as Cohen and prosecutors contend, or whether he said something else.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump said, according to Cohen and prosecutors, as in $150,000.\n\n\"Listen to the recording. See if you hear one-fifty,\" Blanche told jurors.\n\nTRUMP CAMPAIGN HOLDS ITS OWN NEWS CONFERENCE\n\nDonald Trump's campaign staffers held their own news conference outside the courthouse Tuesday morning in the exact same spot where actor Robert De Niro and Jan. 6 officers had just spoken on behalf of Joe Biden's campaign.\n\nJason Miller, Trump's senior campaign advisor, called De Niro \"a washed-up actor,\" and said the news conference showed that the hush money trial was political.\n\n\"After months of saying politics had nothing to do with this trial, they showed up and made a campaign event out of a lower Manhattan trial day for President Trump,\" Miller said.\n\nKaroline Leavitt, the campaign press secretary, called the Biden campaign \"desperate and failing\" and \"pathetic\" and said their event outside the trial was \"a full-blown concession that this trial is a witch hunt that comes from the top.\"\n\nBLANCHE: 'THIS WASN'T A CATCH AND KILL'\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's hush money trial took issue on Tuesday with the notion that there was a conspiracy to suppress negative stories to help Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to American Media Inc.'s $30,000 payment to Dino Sajudin, a former Trump Tower doorman who falsely alleged the former president had fathered a child out of wedlock. It was one of three potentially damaging stories about Trump the tabloid did not run.\n\nBlanche then pointed to former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker's testimony that he saw the doorman story as a potential blockbuster and would gladly have published it if it had been true.\n\n\"This isn't a catch and kill. This is an opportunity,\" Blanche said. \"It was worth too much to catch and kill, full stop.\"\n\nHe also noted Pecker had testified that the tabloid only published about half the stories they purchased.\n\n\"That's meaningful. That matters,\" Blanche told the jury.\n\nHe later targeted prosecutors' portrayal of Karen McDougal's deal with AMI as part of the purported hush money conspiracy, emphasizing testimony from her lawyer and others that she didn't want her claim published.\n\nRather, Blanche said, the former Playboy model wanted to reenergize her career by getting into magazines, according to the testimony -- though McDougal herself didn't testify.\n\n\"This was not a catch-and-kill,\" Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE URGES JURORS TO DISREGARD 'CONSPIRACY' CONCERNS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche implored the jury in Donald Trump's criminal trial to reject the prosecution's contention that he engaged in a conspiracy to influence the 2016 election by involving himself in efforts to bury negative stories about him -- and to reject the allegation that, after the fact, he falsified records of Michael Cohen's payments to hide that conspiracy.\n\n\"The government wants you to believe that President Trump did these things with his records to conceal efforts to promote his successful candidacy in 2016, the year before,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"Even that, even if you find that is true, that is not enough ... it doesn't matter if there's a conspiracy to win an election. Every campaign in this country is a conspiracy to promote a candidate, a group of people who are working together to help somebody win.\"\n\nDEFENSE SAYS TRUMP WATCHES HIS FINANCES CAREFULLY\n\nAfter arguing earlier Tuesday that Donald Trump may not have been fully aware of all his invoices, defense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed to jurors that the former president was a stickler about watching his finances.\n\nMichael Cohen received $420,000 in all from Trump in 2017, a sum that the ex-lawyer and prosecutors in the former president's hush money case have said included the $130,000 reimbursement related to Stormy Daniels, a $50,000 repayment for an unrelated expense and a $60,000 bonus. On top of that, prosecutors have said, there was extra money to cover taxes that would be due on the $130,000 as income -- taxes that wouldn't apply if it had simply been paid as a business expense reimbursement.\n\n\"That is absurd,\" Blanche told jurors, pointing to \"all the other evidence you heard about how carefully President Trump watches his finances.\"\n\nACTOR ROBERT DE NIRO AND JAN. 6 FIRST RESPONDERS SPEAK NEAR TRUMP'S TRIAL\n\nBiden campaign deploys actor Robert De Niro, Jan. 6 first responders near Trump's trial\n\nJoe Biden's campaign sent actor Robert De Niro and two law enforcement officers who defended the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 to an area in lower Manhattan not far from the criminal court where Donald Trump's hush money trial is happening.\n\nSpeaking while the former president was stuck in court, De Niro said Trump wants to \"destroy not only the city but the country and eventually he could destroy the world.\"\n\nAs he spoke, Trump protesters screamed anti-Biden chants.\n\nTRUMP WAS EXTREMELY BUSY WHEN SIGNING CHECKS, BLANCHE SAYS\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche stressed during his summation on Tuesday that Donald Trump was busy during the time when he signed the checks at the heart of the hush money case.\n\n\"It matters where President Trump was,\" Blanche said.\n\nHe noted Trump assistant Madeleine Westerhout had testified that the then-president would sometimes sign checks while meeting with people or while on the phone, not knowing what they were.\n\nBlanche argued it was unreasonable to suggest Trump was aware of the details of every invoice just because he knew of some. \"That is a stretch and that is reasonable doubt, ladies and gentlemen,\" he said.\n\nBLANCHE CRITICIZES PROSECUTIONS USE OF TRUMP'S BOOKS AND MORE\n\nAbout an hour into the defense's closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche took aim at the prosecution's use of excerpts from Trump's books to attempt to portray him as a detail-oriented micromanager who would be fully aware of any money his company was spending.\n\nThe books were from a decade ago, if not older, and were written with the help of ghostwriters, Blanche told the jury.\n\n\"You should be suspicious. That's a red flag,\" Blanche said in an effort to pre-empt the prosecution's closing.\n\nBlanche then started digging into the details of how payments to Michael Cohen were made, first through a trust set up to hold Trump's assets while he was in the White House, then through Trump's personal bank account with checks signed by the then-president.\n\n\"This was a very confusing time for the Trump Organization,\" Blanche said. There were a lot of adjustments being made as Trump's assets were put under the trust's control and it was the first time in decades that Trump wasn't in charge, he added.\n\nAt one point, early in the repayment process in 2017, the then-Trump Organization finance chief emailed a subordinate that it was OK to pay Cohen out of the trust per an agreement with Trump's sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr., who were running the Trump Organization's day-to-day operations at the time. Both were in court on Tuesday.\n\nBlanche questioned why, if prosecutors allege Trump was involved in a conspiracy to conceal the nature of the payments, the sons he put in charge of his company weren't called to the witness stand.\n\nCOHEN WAS TRUMP'S PERSONAL ATTORNEY, BLANCHE REITERATES\n\nA key part of prosecutors' claims in Donald Trump's hush money case is that his former lawyer Michael Cohen wasn't being paid for legal work in 2017, but rather was being reimbursed in a veiled way for the Stormy Daniels payment.\n\nDefense lawyer Todd Blanche pointed to emails and testimony Tuesday showing that Cohen did indeed work on some legal matters for Trump that year.\n\nWhile Cohen characterized that work as \"very minimal,\" Blanche argued otherwise.\n\n\"Cohen lied to you. Cohen lied to you,\" Blanche said, his voice getting more emphatic.\n\nBlanche noted that Cohen went on TV to discuss his role as Trump's personal lawyer and put the title in the signature block of every email he sent.\n\n\"This was not a secret. Michael Cohen was President Trump's personal attorney. Period,\" he said.\n\nBIDEN AND TRUMP CAMPAIGNS HOLD DUELING NEWS CONFERENCES OUTSIDE COURTHOUSE\n\nJoe Biden's campaign announced on Tuesday that it would hold an event with \"special guests\" as closing arguments in Donald Trump's hush money trial are underway.\n\nTrump spokesman Jason Miller said the former president's allies will respond with their own event immediately following Biden's.\n\nHe posted on the social platform X that Biden's allies \"aren't in PA, MI, WI, NV, AZ or GA -- they're outside the Biden Trial against President Trump,\" adding: \"It's always been about politics.\"\n\nPOWERPOINT CLOSING\n\nThe defense in Donald Trump's criminal trial is using a PowerPoint presentation as it begins its summation and tries to convince the jury that the former president is not guilty, instead shifting blame to former lawyer Michael Cohen and the Trump Organization.\n\nTodd Blanche showed jurors copies of the invoices, vouchers and checks that are at the heart of the hush money case -- vouchers and checks he says were entered and prepared by the Trump Organization's accounting department.\n\nThe PowerPoint also notes Cohen sent the invoices for his services. None of the invoices were sent directly to Trump, Blanche said.\n\nBLANCHE TAKES AIM AT COHEN'S TESTIMONY\n\nInsisting that prosecutors haven't proven their case, defense lawyer Todd Blanche told jurors during closing arguments Tuesday morning that they \"should want and expect more\" than key prosecution witness Michael Cohen's testimony, or that of a Trump Organization employee accounts payable staffer talking about how she processed invoices, or the testimony given by Stormy Daniels' former lawyer Keith Davidson.\n\nBlanche argued that Davidson \"was really just trying to extort money from President Trump\" in the lead-up to the 2016 election.\n\n\"The consequences of the lack of proof that you all heard over the past five weeks is simple: is a not guilty verdict, period,\" Blanche said.\n\nBlanche further laid into Cohen and his testimony, telling jurors he'll come up repeatedly throughout the defense's summation.\n\n\"You're going to hear me talk a lot about Michael Cohen, and for good reason. You can not convict President Trump, you can not convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the word of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche said. Cohen \"told you a number of things that were lies, pure and simple,\" the lawyer added.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.nysun.com/article/tiffany-trump-makes-rare-public-appearance-at-fathers-trial-after-michael-cohen-describes-plot-to-extort-her-with-photos", "title": "Tiffany Trump Makes Rare Public Appearance at Father's Trial After Michael Cohen Describes Plot To 'Extort' Her With Photos", "body": "Tiffany Trump joins a cohort of President Trump's family at court for the closing arguments.\n\nPresident Trump's younger daughter, Tiffany Trump, made a rare public appearance at her father's trial at Lower Manhattan Tuesday, after a key witness, Michael Cohen, last week discussed his role in defusing a plot to \"extort her\" while Mr. Trump was president.\n\nMs. Trump, along with other members of the former president's family, including his sons Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump and his daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, who is now co-chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, appeared solemn-faced at court for closing arguments Tuesday.\n\nThe former president's third and current wife, Melania Trump, his youngest son, Barron, and his elder daughter, Ivanka, have been absent from the trial, which centers on hush-money allegedly paid in 2016 to a porn star, Stormy Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, to keep her from publicizing a one-time sexual encounter she claims to have had with Mr. Trump in 2006 at a celebrity golf tournament at Lake Tahoe.\n\nMs. Trump's appearance came after Mr. Trump's former fixer, Cohen, disclosed in testimony last week that she had been the subject of an alleged extortion plot involving photos.\n\nIn testimony on Thursday, an attorney for Mr. Trump, Todd Blanche, pressed Cohen during cross-examination about the alleged extortion attempt in order to show that Cohen had many reasons to communicate with Mr. Trump, who was by then the president, beyond reimbursing the alleged hush-money payment.\n\n\"You agree with me, right, that you had a lot going on both in your personal life and with President Trump in those first two weeks of October?\" Mr. Blanche said.\n\nCohen answered that he agreed with him.\n\nMr. Blanche added, \"You recall on October 25th, you recall her communicating with you concerns about somebody trying to blackmail her?\" He characterized the call as a \"potential extortion attempt.\" Cohen again agreed.\n\nMr. Blanche also noted that Mr. Trump was coordinating an opening for a new hotel at Washington, D.C., in late October, suggesting that there were at least three topics Cohen could have been meeting with Mr. Trump to discuss.\n\n\"So was fixing Tiffany Trump's situation important to you?\" Mr. Blanche said.\n\n\"It was important I take care of things but it was not personally important to me,\" Cohen said.\n\n\"Wouldn't that be something you updated her father about when you spoke the next morning?\" Mr. Blanche asked, to which Cohen replied, \"No sir.\"\n\nIn October 2016, as Cohen was working to pay Ms. Clifford, Ms. Trump joined her father, her half-sister, and her half-brothers -- other than Barron -- for a sit down interview with a former aide to President Clinton, George Stephanopoulos, about the opening of the new Trump hotel at Washington. During the interview, a rare public appearance for Ms. Trump, she said she was applying to law school and hoped to join the family business.\n\nIn the intervening eight years, Ms. Trump has graduated from law school at the prestigious Georgetown University Law Center at Washington, and married the scion of a wealthy Lebanese family with major business interests at Lagos. She has 1.3 million followers on Instagram, where she most recently posted pictures from her nuptials. It's unclear what Ms. Trump is doing professionally and whether she's passed the bar -- and, if so, where.\n\nShe is the daughter of Mr. Trump and his second wife, Marla Maples. Her father's messy 1990 divorce from his first wife, Ivana, sparked by his affair with Ms. Maples, became legendary in the annals of tabloid journalism, setting a precedent for coverage of future high-wattage divorces.", "source": {"uri": "nysun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "russell_payne@nysun.com", "name": "Russell Payne", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Cohen_(lawyer)", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Michael Cohen (lawyer)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiffany_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tiffany Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extortion", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": It's as true right now as it was on April 22. And that is President Trump is innocent. He did not commit any crimes, and the district attorney has not met their burden of proof -- period. The evidence is all in,\" Blanche said.\n\n\"The evidence should leave you wanting more. You should want and expect more than the testimony of Michael Cohen,\" Blanche stated.\n\nDefense attorney Todd Blanche maintained that the case is about documents, not Stormy Daniels. This case is not about an encounter with Stormy Daniels 18 years ago.\"\n\n\"An encounter that President Trump has unequivocally and repeatedly denied occurred,\" the Republican's lawyer said.\n\n\"You cannot convict President Trump of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt on the words of Michael Cohen.
